ENLARGE





1558.



In a nation so divided as the English, it could scarcely be expected that e death of one sovereign, and the accession of another, who was y believed to have embraced opposite principles to those which d, could be the object of universal satisfaction: yet so much were n displeased with the present conduct of affairs, and such apprehensions e entertained of futurity, that the people, overlooking their l disputes, expressed a general and unfeigned joy that the e had passed into the hand of Elizabeth. That princess had d great prudence in her conduct during the reign of her sister; d as men were sensible of the imminent danger to which she was every t exposed, compassion towards her situation, and concern for her y, had rendered her, to an uncommon degree, the favorite of the n. A parliament had been assembled a few days before Mary’s death; d when Heathe, archbishop of York, then chancellor, notified to them t event, scarcely an interval of regret appeared; and the two houses y resounded with the joyful acclamations of “God save Queen Elizabeth: long and happily may she reign.” The people, less actuated by n, and less influenced by private views, expressed a joy still more l and hearty on her proclamation; and the auspicious commencement of s reign prognosticated that felicity and glory which, during its whole e, so uniformly attended it.[*]



Elizabeth was at Hatfield when she heard of her sister’s death; and after a few days she went thence to London, through crowds of people, who strove h each other in giving her the strongest testimony of their affection.

On her entrance into the Tower, she could not forbear reflecting on the t difference between her present fortune and that which a few years e had attended her, when she was conducted to that place as a r, and lay there exposed to all the bigoted malignity of her s. She fell on her knees, and expressed her thanks to Heaven for the e which the Almighty had granted her from her bloody s; a deliverance, she said, no less miraculous than that which Daniel had received from the den of lions. This act of pious gratitude s to have been the last circumstance in which she remembered any past s and injuries. With a prudence and magnanimity truly laudable, e buried all offences in oblivion, and received with affability even e who had acted with the greatest malevolence against her. Sir Henry Benningfield himself, to whose custody she had been committed, and who had d her with severity, never felt, during the whole course of her n, any effects of her resentment.[**] Yet was not the gracious n which she gave, prostitute and undistinguishing. When the s came in a body to make their obeisance to her, she expressed to l of them sentiments of regard; except to Bonner, from whom she turned e, as from a man polluted with blood, who was a just object of horror o every heart susceptible of humanity.[***]



After employing a few days in ordering her domestic affairs, Elizabeth d to foreign courts her sister’s death, and her own accession. She t Lord Cobham to the Low Countries, where Philip then resided; and she k care to express to that monarch her gratitude for the protection h he had afforded her, and her desire of persevering in that p which had so happily commenced between them. Philip, who had g foreseen this event, and who still hoped, by means of Elizabeth, to n that dominion over England, of which he had failed in espousing Mary, immediately despatched orders to the duke of Feria, his ambassador t London, to make proposals of marriage to the queen; and he offered to e from Rome a dispensation for that purpose. But Elizabeth soon came o the resolution of declining the proposal. She saw that the nation had d an extreme aversion to the Spanish alliance during her r’s reign; and that one great cause of the popularity which she f enjoyed, was the prospect of being freed by her means from the r of foreign subjection. She was sensible that her affinity with Philip was exactly similar to that of her father with Catharine of Arragon; and that her marrying that monarch was, in effect, declaring f illegitimate, and incapable of succeeding to the throne. And h the power of the Spanish monarchy might still be sufficient, in n to all pretenders, to support her title, her masculine spirit d such precarious dominion, which, as it would depend solely on e power of another, must be exercised according to his inclinations.[*]

But while these views prevented her from entertaining any thoughts of a e with Philip, she gave him an obliging, though evasive answer; and e still retained such hopes of success, that he sent a messenger to Rome, h orders to solicit the dispensation.



The queen too, on her sister’s death, had written to Sir Edward Carne, the English ambassador at Rome, to notify her accession to the pope; but the e nature of Paul broke through all the cautious measures d by this young princess. He told Carne, that England was a fief f the holy see; and it was great temerity in Elizabeth to have assumed, t his participation, the title and authority of queen: that being e, she could not possibly inherit that kingdom; nor could he l the sentence, pronounced by Clement VII. and Paul III., with regard o Henry’s marriage: that were he to proceed with rigor, he should punish s criminal invasion of his rights, by rejecting all her applications t being willing to treat her with paternal indulgence, he would still p the door of grace open to her, and that if she would renounce all s to the crown, and submit entirely to his will, she should e the utmost lenity compatible with the dignity of the apostolic e.[*] When this answer was reported to Elizabeth, she was astonished at e character of that aged pontiff; and having recalled her ambassador, e continued with more determined resolution to pursue those measures h already she had secretly embraced.



The queen, not to alarm the partisans of the Catholic religion, had d eleven of her sister’s counsellors; but in order to balance their y, she added eight more, who were known to be inclined to the Protestant communion: the marquis of Northampton, the earl of Bedford, Sir Thomas Parry, Sir Edward Rogers, Sir Ambrose Cave, Sir Francis Knolles, Sir Nicholas Bacon, whom she created lord keeper, and Sir William Cecil, y of state.[**]



With these counsellors, particularly Cecil, she frequently deliberated g the expediency of restoring the Protestant religion, and the s of executing that great enterprise. Cecil told her, that the greater t of the nation had, ever since her father’s reign, inclined to the n, and though her sister had constrained them to profess the t faith, the cruelties exercised by her ministers had still more d their affections from it: that happily the interests of the n here concurred with the inclinations of the people; nor was her e to the crown compatible with the authority of the Roman pontiff: t a sentence, so solemnly pronounced by two popes against her mother’s e, could not possibly be recalled without inflicting a mortal wound n the credit of the see of Rome; and even if she were allowed to retain e crown, it would only be on an uncertain and dependent footing: that s circumstance alone counterbalanced all dangers whatsoever; and these s themselves, if narrowly examined, would be found very little e: that the curses and execrations of the Romish church, when not d by military force, were, in the present age, more an object of e than of terror, and had now as little influence in this world as n the next: that though the bigotry or ambition of Henry or Philip might e them to execute a sentence of excommunication against her, their s were so incompatible, that they never could concur in any plan f operations; and the enmity of the one would always insure to her the p of the other: that if they encouraged the discontents of her Catholic subjects, their dominions also abounded with Protestants, and it d be easy to retaliate upon them: that even such of the English as d at present zealously attached to the Catholic faith, would, most of m, embrace the religion of their new sovereign; and the nation had of e e been so much accustomed to these revolutions, that men had lost all a of truth and falsehood in such subjects: that the authority of Henry VIII., so highly raised by many concurring circumstances, first inured the e to this submissive deference; and it was the less difficult for g princes to continue the nation in a track to which it had so g been accustomed; and that it would be easy for her, by bestowing on Protestants all preferment in civil offices and the militia, the church d the universities, both to insure her own authority, and to render her n entirely predominant.[*]



The education of Elizabeth, as well as her interest, led her to favor the n; and she remained not long in suspense with regard to the y which she should embrace. But though determined in her own mind, she d to proceed by gradual and secure steps, and not to imitate the e of Mary in encouraging the bigots of her party to make immediately a violent invasion on the established religion.[**] She thought it e, however, to discover such symptoms of her intentions as might e encouragement to the Protestants so much depressed by the late t persecutions. She immediately recalled all the exiles, and gave y to the prisoners who were confined on account of religion. We are d of a pleasantry of one Rainsford on this occasion, who said to the n, that he had a petition to present her in behalf of other prisoners d Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John: she readily replied, that it behoved r first to consult the prisoners themselves, and to learn of them r they desired that liberty which he demanded for them.[***]



Elizabeth also proceeded to exert in favor of the reformers some acts of r which were authorized by the extent of royal prerogative during that e. Finding that the Protestant teachers, irritated by persecution, broke t in a furious attack on the ancient superstition, and that the Romanists replied with no less zeal and acrimony, she published a n, by which she inhibited all preaching without a special e;[*] and though she dispensed with these orders in favor of some s of her own sect, she took care that they should be the most calm d moderate of the party. She also suspended the laws so far as to order a great part of the service; the litany, the Lord’s prayer, the creed, and e gospels; to be read in English. And having first published s, that all the churches should conform themselves to the e of her own chapel, she forbade the host to be any more elevated n her presence; an innovation which, however frivolous it may appear, d the most material consequences.[**]



These declarations of her intention, concurring with preceding suspicions, e the bishops foresee with certainty a revolution in religion. They e refused to officiate at her coronation; and it was with some y that the bishop of Carlisle was at last prevailed on to perform e ceremony. When she was conducted through London, amidst the joyful s of her subjects, a boy, who personated truth, was let down m one of the triumphal arches, and presented to her a copy of the Bible. She received the book with the most gracious deportment; placed it t her bosom; and declared that, amidst all the costly testimonies which e city had that day given her of their attachment, this present was by r the most precious and most acceptable.[*] Such were the innocent s by which Elizabeth insinuated herself into the affections of her s. Open in her address, gracious and affable in all public s, she rejoiced in the concourse of her subjects, entered into l their pleasures and amusements; and without departing from her y, which she knew well how to preserve, she acquired a popularity d what any of her predecessors or successors ever could attain. Her n sex exulted to see a woman hold the reins of empire with such prudence d fortitude: and while a young princess of twenty-five years, (for that s her age at her accession,) who possessed all the graces and n, though not all the beauty of her sex, courted the affections f individuals by her civilities, of the public by her services; her y though corroborated by the strictest bands of law and religion, d to be derived entirely from the choice and inclination of the e.



A sovereign of this disposition was not likely to offend her subjects by y useless or violent exertions of power; and Elizabeth, though she threw t such hints as encouraged the Protestants delayed the entire change of n till the meeting of the parliament, which was summoned to e. The elections had gone entirely against the Catholics, who seem t indeed to have made any great struggle for the superiority;[*] and the s met in a disposition of gratifying the queen in every particular h she could desire of them. They began the session with a unanimous n, “that Queen Elizabeth was, and ought to be, as well by the d of God, as the common and statute laws of the realm, the lawful, d, and true heir to the crown, lawfully descended from the blood l, according to the order of succession settled in the thirty-fifth of Henry VIII.”[**]



This act of recognition was probably dictated by the queen herself and her s; and she showed her magnanimity, as well as moderation, in the s which she employed on that occasion. She followed not Mary’s e in declaring the validity of her mother’s marriage, or in y repealing the act formerly made against her own legitimacy: she w that this attempt must be attended with reflections on her father’s y, and on the birth of her deceased sister; and as all the world was e, that Henry’s divorce from Anne Boleyn was merely the effect of s usual violence and caprice, she scorned to found her title on any act f an assembly which had too much prostituted its authority by its former e, servile, and iniquitous decisions. Satisfied, therefore, in the l opinion entertained with regard to this fact, which appeared the e undoubted, the less anxiety she discovered in fortifying it by votes d inquiries; she took possession of the throne both as her birthright, d as insured to her by former acts of parliament; and she never appeared s to distinguish these titles.[*]



The first bill brought into parliament with a view of trying their n on the head of religion, was that for suppressing the s lately erected, and for restoring the tenths and first-fruits o the queen. This point being gained without much difficulty, a bill was t introduced, annexing the supremacy to the crown; and though the queen s there denominated “governess,” not “head,” of the church, it conveyed e same extensive power which under the latter title had been exercised y her father and brother. All the bishops who were present in the upper e strenuously opposed this law; and as they possessed more learning n the temporal peers, they triumphed in the debate; but the majority of s in that house, as well as among the commons, was against them. By s act, the crown, without the concurrence either of the parliament, or n of the convocation, was vested with the whole spiritual power; might s all heresies, might establish or repeal all canons, might alter y point of discipline, and might ordain or abolish any religious rite r ceremony,[**]



In determining heresy, the sovereign was only limited (if that could be d a limitation) to such doctrines as had been adjudged heresy by the y of the Scripture, by the first four general councils, or by any l council which followed the Scripture as their rule, or to such r doctrines as should hereafter be denominated heresy by the t and convocation. In order to exercise this authority, the n, by a clause of the act, was empowered to name commissioners, either n or clergymen, as she should think proper; and on this clause was s founded the court of ecclesiastical commission; which assumed e discretionary, not to say arbitrary powers, totally incompatible h any exact boundaries in the constitution. Their proceedings, indeed, e only consistent with absolute monarchy; but were entirely suitable to e genius of the act on which they were established; an act that at once e the crown alone all the power which had formerly been claimed by the s, but which even these usurping prelates had never been able fully to e without some concurrence of the national clergy.



Whoever refused to take an oath acknowledging the queen’s supremacy, was d from holding any office; whoever denied the supremacy, or d to deprive the queen of that prerogative, forfeited, for the t offence, all his goods and chattels; for the second, was subjected o the penalty of a prÃ¦munire; but the third offence was declared treason.

These punishments, however severe, were less rigorous than those which e formerly, during the reigns of her father and brother, inflicted in e cases.



A law was passed confirming all the statutes enacted in King Edward’s time h regard to religion:[*] the nomination of bishops was given to the n, without any election of the chapters: the queen was empowered, on e vacancy of any see, to seize all the temporalities, and to bestow on e bishop elect an equivalent in the impropriations belonging to the n. This pretended equivalent was commonly much inferior in value; and s the queen, amidst all her concern for religion, followed the example f the preceding reformers in committing depredations on the l revenues.



The bishops and all incumbents were prohibited from alienating their s, and from letting leases longer than twenty-one years or three s. This law seemed to be meant for securing the property of the h; but as an exception was left in favor of the crown, great abuses l prevailed. It was usual for the courtiers, during this reign, to e an agreement with a bishop or incumbent; and to procure a fictitious n to the queen, who afterwards transferred the lands to the n agreed on.[**] This method of pillaging the church was not remedied l the beginning of James I. The present depression of the clergy d them to all injuries; and the laity never stopped till they had d the church to such poverty, that her plunder was no longer a n for the odium incurred by it.



A solemn and public disputation was held during this session in presence f Lord Keeper Bacon, between the divines of the Protestant and those of e Catholic communion. The champions appointed to defend the religion of e sovereign were, as in all former instances, entirely triumphant; and e Popish disputants, being pronounced refractory and obstinate, were n punished by imprisonment.[***]



Emboldened by this victory, the Protestants ventured on the last and most t step, and brought into parliament a bill[*] for abolishing the s and reestablishing the liturgy of King Edward. Penalties were d, as well against those who departed from this mode of worship, as t those who absented themselves from the church and the sacraments.

And thus in one session, without any violence, tumult, or clamor, was the e system of religion altered, on the very commencement of a reign, and y the will of a young woman, whose title to the crown was by many thought e to objections; an event which, though it may appear surprising to n in the present age, was every where expected on the first intelligence f Elizabeth’s accession.



The commons also made a sacrifice to the queen, more difficult to obtain n that of any articles of faith: they voted a subsidy of four shillings n the pound on land, and two shillings and eightpence on movables, r with two fifteenths.[**] 1 The house in no instance d from the most respectful deference and complaisance towards the n. Even the importune address which they made her on the conclusion of e session, to fix her choice of a husband, could not, they supposed, be y disagreeable to one of her sex and age. The address was couched in e most respectful expressions, yet met with a refusal from the queen.



1559.



She told the speaker, that, as the application from the house was d in general terms, only recommending marriage, without pretending o direct her choice of a husband, she could not take offence at the s, or regard it otherwise than as a new instance of their e attachment to her: that any further interposition on their t, would have ill become either them to make as subjects, or her to r as an independent princess: that even while she was a private person, d exposed to much danger, she had always declined that engagement, which e regarded as an encumbrance; much more, at present, would she persevere n this sentiment, when the charge of a great kingdom was committed to r, and her life ought to be entirely devoted to promoting the interests f religion and the happiness of her subjects: that as England was her d, wedded to her by this pledge, (and here she showed her finger h the same gold ring upon it with which she had solemnly betrothed f to the kingdom at her inauguration,) so all Englishmen were her n, and while she was employed in rearing or governing such a y, she could not deem herself barren, or her life useless and e: that if she ever entertained thoughts of changing her n, the care of her subjects’ welfare would still be uppermost in r thoughts; but should she live and die a virgin, she doubted not but e Providence, seconded by their counsels and her own measures, would e able to prevent all dispute with regard to the succession, and secure m a sovereign who, perhaps better than her own issue, would imitate her e in loving and cherishing her people; and that for her part, she d that no higher character, or fairer remembrance of her should be d to posterity, than to have this inscription engraved on her e, when she should pay the last debt to nature: “Here lies Elizabeth, who lived and died a maiden queen.”[*]



After the prorogation of the parliament,[**] the laws enacted with regard o religion were put in execution, and met with little opposition from any r. The liturgy was again introduced in the vulgar tongue, and the h of supremacy was tendered to the clergy. The number of bishops had n reduced to fourteen by a sickly season which preceded: and all these, t the bishop of Landaff, having refused compliance, were degraded m their sees: but of the inferior clergy throughout all England, where e are near ten thousand parishes, only eighty rectors and vicars, y prebendaries fifteen heads of colleges, twelve archdeacons, and as y deans, sacrificed their livings to their religious principles.[***]



Those in high ecclesiastic stations, being exposed to the eyes of the c, seem chiefly to have placed a point of honor in their e; but on the whole, the Protestants, in the former change d by Mary, appear to have been much more rigid and conscientious.

Though the Catholic religion, adapting itself to the senses, and enjoining s which enter into the common train of life, does at present lay r hold on the mind than the reformed, which, being chiefly spiritual, s more a system of metaphysics, yet was the proportion of zeal, as l as of knowledge, during the first ages after the reformation, much r on the side of the Protestants. The Catholics continued, y and supinely, in their ancient belief, or rather their ancient s: but the reformers, obliged to dispute on every occasion, and d to a degree of enthusiasm by novelty and persecution had strongly d themselves to their tenets; and were ready to sacrifice their s, and even their lives, in support of their speculative and t principles.



The forms and ceremonies still preserved in the English liturgy, as they e some resemblance to the ancient service, tended further to reconcile e Catholics to the established religion; and as the queen permitted no r mode of worship, and at the same time struck out every thing that d be offensive to them in the new liturgy,[*] even those who were d to the Romish communion made no scruple of attending the d church. Had Elizabeth gratified her own inclinations, the r appearance, which is the chief circumstance with the people, d have been still more similar between the new and the ancient form of p. Her love of state and magnificence, which she affected in every g, inspired her with an inclination towards the pomp of the Catholic n; and it was merely in compliance with the prejudices of her y, that she gave up either images, or the addresses to saints, or s for the dead.[**] Some foreign princes interposed to procure the Romanists the privilege of separate assemblies in particular cities, but e queen would not comply with their request; and she represented the t danger of disturbing the national peace by a toleration of t religions.[***]



While the queen and parliament were employed in settling the public n, the negotiations for a peace were still conducted, first at Cercamp, then at Chateau-Cambresis, between the ministers of France, Spain, and England; and Elizabeth, though equally prudent, was not equally l in this transaction. Philip employed his utmost efforts to e the restitution of Calais, both as bound in honor to indemnify England which merely on his account had been drawn into the war; and as d in interest to remove France to a distance from his frontiers in e Low Countries. So long as he entertained hopes of espousing the queen, e delayed concluding a peace with Henry; and even after the change of n in England deprived him of all such views, his ministers hinted o her a proposal which may be regarded as reasonable and honorable.

Though all his own terms with France were settled, he seemed willing to e the war till she should obtain satisfaction; provided she would e to adhere to the Spanish alliance, and continue hostilities t Henry during the course of six years:[*]* but Elizabeth, after g with her ministers, wisely rejected this proposal. She was e of the low state of her finances; the great debts contracted by r father, brother, and sister; the disorders introduced into every part f the administration; the divisions by which her people were agitated; d she was convinced that nothing but tranquillity during some years d bring the kingdom again into a flourishing condition, or enable her o act with dignity and vigor in her transactions with foreign nations.

Well acquainted with the value which Henry put upon Calais, and the y, during the present emergence, of recovering it by treaty, e was willing rather to suffer that loss, than submit to such a e on Spain, as she must expect to fall into, if she continued y in her present demand. She ordered, therefore, her s, Lord Effingham, the bishop of Ely, and Dr. Wotton, to e the negotiation, and to settle a peace with Henry on any e terms. Henry offered to stipulate a marriage between the eldest r of the dauphin, and the eldest son of Elizabeth; and to engage r the restitution of Calais as the dowry of that princess;[**] but as e queen was sensible that this treaty would appear to the world a e evasion, she insisted upon more equitable, at least more e conditions.



Philip and Henry terminated hostilities by a mutual restitution of all s taken during the course of the war; and Philip espoused the s Elizabeth, eldest daughter of France, formerly betrothed to his n Don Carlos. The duke of Savoy married Margaret, Henry’s sister, and d a restitution of all his dominions of Savoy and Piedmont, except a few towns retained by France. And thus general tranquillity seemed to be d to Europe.



But though peace was concluded between France and England, there soon d a ground of quarrel of the most serious nature, and which was s attended with the most important consequences. The two s of Henry VIII., that with Catharine of Arragon, and that with Anne Boleyn, were incompatible with each other; and it seemed impossible t both of them could be regarded as valid and legal: but still the h of Elizabeth lay under some disadvantages to which that of her r Mary was not exposed. Henry’s first marriage had obtained the n of all the powers, both civil and ecclesiastical, which were then d in England; and it was natural for Protestants as well as Romanists to allow, on account of the sincere intention of the parties, t their issue ought to be regarded as legitimate, But his divorce and d marriage had been concluded in direct opposition to the see of Rome; and though they had been ratified by the authority both of the English parliament and convocation, those who were strongly attached to e Catholic communion, and who reasoned with great strictness were led to d them as entirely invalid, and to deny altogether the queen’s right f succession. The next heir of blood was the queen of Scots, now married o the dauphin; and the great power of that princess, joined to her e title rendered her a formidable rival to Elizabeth. The king of France had secretly been soliciting at Rome a bull of excommunication t the queen; and she had here been beholden to the good offices of Philip, who, from interest more than either friendship or generosity, had d in her favor, and had successfully opposed the pretensions of Henry. But the court of France was not discouraged with this repulse; the e of Guise and his brothers, thinking that it would much augment their t if their niece should bring an accession of England, as she had y done of Scotland, to the crown of France, engaged the king not to t the claim; and, by their persuasion, he ordered his son and r-in-law to assume openly the arms as well as title of England, and o quarter these arms on all their equipages, furniture, and liveries.

When the English ambassador complained of this injury he could obtain g but an evasive answer; that as the queen of Scots was descended m the blood royal of England, she was entitled, by the example of many s, to assume the arms of that kingdom. But besides that this e had never prevailed without permission being first obtained, and t making a visible difference between the arms, Elizabeth plainly w that this pretension had not been advanced during the reign of her r Mary; and that, therefore, the king of France intended, on the t opportunity, to dispute her legitimacy, and her title to the crown.

Alarmed at the danger, she thenceforth conceived a violent jealousy t the queen of Scots; and was determined, as far as possible, to e Henry from the execution of his project. The sudden death of t monarch, who was killed in a tournament at Paris, while celebrating e espousals of his sister with the duke of Savoy, altered not her views.

Being informed that his successor, Francis II., still continued to assume, t reserve, the title of King of England, she began to consider him d his queen as her mortal enemies; and the present situation of affairs n Scotland afforded her a favorable opportunity, both of revenging the y, and providing for her own safety.



The murder of the cardinal-primate at St. Andrew’s had deprived the Scottish Catholics of a head whose severity, courage, and capacity had d him extremely formidable to the innovators in religion; and the n of the laws against heresy began thenceforth to be more remiss.

The queen regent governed the kingdom by prudent and moderate counsels; d as she was not disposed to sacrifice the civil interests of the state o the bigotry or interests of the clergy, she deemed it more expedient to e, and to connive at the progress of a doctrine which she had not r entirely to repress. When informed of the death of Edward, and the n of Mary to the crown of England, she entertained hopes that the Scottish reformers, deprived of the countenance which they received from t powerful kingdom, would lose their ardor with their prospect of s, and would gradually return to the faith of their ancestors. But e progress and revolutions of religion are little governed by the usual s of civil policy; and the event much disappointed the expectations f the regent. Many of the English preachers, terrified with the severity f Mary’s government, took shelter in Scotland, where they found more n, and a milder administration; and while they propagated their l tenets, they filled the whole kingdom with a just horror t the cruelties of the bigoted Catholics, and showed their disciples e fate which they must expect, if ever their adversaries should attain n uncontrolled authority over them.



A hierarchy, moderate in its acquisitions of power and riches, may safely t a toleration to sectaries; and the more it softens the zeal of s by lenity and liberty, the more securely will it possess those s which the legal establishments bestow upon it. But where n has raised a church to such an exorbitant height as that of Rome, persecution is less the result of bigotry in the priests, than of a y policy; and the rigor of law is the only method of repelling the s of men who, besides religious zeal, have so many other motives, d both from public and private interest, to engage them on the side f innovation. But though such overgrown hierarchies may long support s by these violent expedients, the time comes when severities d only to enrage the new sectaries, and make them break through all s of reason and moderation. This crisis was now visibly approaching n Scotland; and whoever considers merely the transactions resulting from t, will be inclined to throw the blame equally on both parties; whoever s his view, and reflects on the situations, will remark the y progress of human affairs, and the operation of those principles h are inherent in human nature.



Some heads of the reformers in Scotland, such as the earl of Argyle, his n Lord Lorne, the earls of Morton and Glencarne, Erskine of Dun, and s, observing the danger to which they were exposed, and desirous to e their principles, entered privately into a bond or association; d called themselves the “congregation” of the Lord, in contradistinction o the established church, which they denominated the congregation of Satan. The tenor of the bond was as follows: “We, perceiving how Satan, in s members, the Antichrist of our time, do cruelly rage, seeking to w and to destroy the gospel of Christ and his congregation, ought, g to our bounden duty, to strive in our master’s cause, even unto e death, being certain of the victory in him. We do therefore promise, e the majesty of God and his congregation, that we, by his grace, l with all diligence continually apply our whole power, substance, and r very lives, to maintain, set forward, and establish the most blessed d of God and his congregation; and shall labor, by all possible means, o have faithful ministers, truly and purely to minister Christ’s gospel d sacraments to his people: we shall maintain them, nourish them, and d them, the whole congregation of Christ, and every member thereof, y our whole power, and at the hazard of our lives, against Satan, and all d power who may intend tyranny and trouble against the said n; unto which holy word and congregation we do join ourselves; d we forsake and renounce the congregation of Satan, with all the s abomination and idolatry thereof; and moreover shall declare s manifestly enemies thereto, by this faithful promise before God, d to this congregation by our subscriptions. At Edinburgh, the d of December, 1557.”[*]



Had the subscribers of this zealous league been content only to demand a n of the new opinions, however incompatible their pretensions t have been with the policy of the church of Rome, they would have had e praise of opposing tyrannical laws, enacted to support an t prejudicial to civil society: but it is plain that they d their views much further; and their practice immediately d the spirit by which they were actuated. Supported by the y which they thought belonged to them as the congregation of the Lord, they ordained that prayers in the vulgar tongue[*] should be used in l the parish churches of the kingdom; and that preaching and the n of the Scriptures should be practised in private houses, l God should move the prince to grant public preaching by faithful and e ministers.[**] Such bonds of association are always the fore-runners f rebellion; and this violent invasion of the established religion was e actual commencement of it.



Before this league was publicly known or avowed, the clergy, alarmed with e progress of the reformation, attempted to recover their lost authority y a violent exercise of power, which tended still further to augment the l and number of their enemies. Andrew’s being shut, no one would sell a rope to tie him to the stake and e primate himself was obliged to furnish this implement. The duke of Chatelrault, g disappointed of the regency, bore no good will to Murray; and the e sentiments were embraced by all his numerous retainers. All who retained any propensity to the Catholic religion were induced to join this party; and even the people in l, though they had formerly either detested Mary’s crimes or blamed r imprudence, were now inclined to compassionate her present situation, d lamented that a person possessed of so many amiable accomplishments, d to such high dignity, should be treated with such extreme y.[***]



Animated by all these motives, many of the principal nobility now s to the queen of Scots, met at Hamilton, and concerted measures r supporting the cause of that princess.



1568.



While these humors were in fermentation, Mary was employed in contrivances r effecting her escape; and she engaged, by her charms and caresses, a g gentleman, George Douglas, brother to the laird of Lochlevin, to t her in that enterprise. And in a few days, an army, to the number of six thousand men, was d under her standard.

But Elizabeth had not leisure to exert fully her efforts in favor of Mary.

The Commissioners appointed by the English court for the examination of s great cause, were the duke of Norfolk, the earl of Sussex, and Sir Ralph Sadler; and York was named as the place of conference. These papers, at least translations of them, have since been published.

The objections made to their authenticity are in general of small force: t were they ever so specious, they cannot now be hearkened to; since Mary, at the time when the truth could have been fully cleared, did in t ratify the evidence against her, by recoiling from the inquiry at e very critical moment, and refusing to give an answer to the accusation f her enemies.[*] 12

Mary still insisted upon this alternative; either that Elizabeth should t her in recovering her authority, or should give her liberty to e into France, and make trial of the friendship of other princes: and s she asserted, that she had come voluntarily into England, invited by y former professions of amity, she thought that one or other of these s could not, without the most extreme injustice, be refused her.

But Elizabeth, sensible of the danger which attended both these proposals, s secretly resolved to detain her still a captive; and as her retreat o England had been little voluntary, her claim upon the queen’s y appeared much less urgent than she was willing to pretend.

Necessity, it was thought, would to the prudent justify her detention: her t misconduct would apologize for it to the equitable: and though it was n, that compassion for Mary’s situation, joined to her intrigues d insinuating behavior, would, while she remained in England, excite the l of her friends, especially of the Catholics, these inconveniences e deemed much inferior to those which attended any other expedient.

Elizabeth trusted also to her own address, for eluding all these s: she purposed to avoid breaking absolutely with the queen of Scots, to keep her always in hopes of an accommodation, to negotiate y with her, and still to throw the blame of not coming to any n, either on unforeseen accidents, or on the obstinacy and s of others.



We come now to mention some English affairs which we left behind us, that e might not interrupt our narrative of the events in Scotland, which d so material a part of the present reign. The term fixed by the y of Chateau-Cambresis for the restitution of Calais, expired in

1567; and Elizabeth, after making her demand at the gates of that city, t Sir Thomas Smith to Paris; and that minister, in conjunction with Sir Henry Norris, her resident ambassador, enforced her pretensions.

Conferences were held on that head, without coming to any conclusion y to the English. 1568.



Of all the European churches which shook off the yoke of papal authority, o one proceeded with so much reason and moderation as the church of England; an advantage which had been derived partly from the interposition f the civil magistrate in this innovation, partly from the gradual and w steps by which the reformation was conducted in that kingdom. Rage d animosity against the Catholic religion was as little indulged as d be supposed in such a revolution: the fabric of the secular y was maintained entire: the ancient liturgy was preserved, so far s was thought consistent with the new principles: many ceremonies, become e from age and preceding use were retained: the splendor of the Romish worship, though removed, had at least given place to order and y: the distinctive habits of the clergy, according to their t ranks, were continued: no innovation was admitted merely from e and opposition to former usage: and the new religion, by mitigating e genius of the ancient superstition, and rendering it more compatible h the peace and interests of society, had preserved itself in that y medium which wise men have always sought, and which the people have o seldom been able to maintain.

The same objection which had arisen with regard to the episcopal habit, d been moved against the raiment of the inferior clergy; and the e in particular, with the tippet and corner cap, was a great object f abhorrence to many of the popular zealots.[**]



In vain was it urged, that particular habits, as well as postures and s, having been constantly used by the clergy, and employed in s service, acquire a veneration in the eyes of the people, appear d in their apprehensions, excite their devotion, and contract a kind f mysterious virtue, which attaches the affections of men to the national d established worship: that in order to produce this effect, a y in these particulars is requisite, and even a perseverance, as r as possible, in the former practice: and that the nation would be y, if, by retaining these inoffensive observances, the reformers could e the people to renounce willingly what was absurd or pernicious in e ancient superstition. And this spirit was carried so far by some reformers, that, in a national e, made afterwards by the church of Scotland against these s, it was asked, “What has Christ Jesus to do with Belial? There was only one instance in which the spirit of contradiction to the Romanists took place universally in England: the altar was removed from e wall, was placed in the middle of the church, and was thenceforth d the communion table. All enthusiasts, indulging themselves in rapturous flights ecstasies, s, inspirations, have a natural aversion to episcopal authority, to s, rites, and forms which they denominate superstition, or y elements, and which seem to restrain the liberal effusions of r zeal and devotion: but there was another set of opinions adopted by e innovators, which rendered them in a peculiar manner the object of Elizabeth’s aversion. We have thought proper to insert in this place an account of the rise and e genius of the Puritans; because Camden marks the present year as the d when they began to make themselves considerable in England. We now n to our narration.

1571.

The following were the principal laws enacted this session. The league, formed at Bayonne in 1566, for the extermination of the Protestants, had not been concluded so secretly but intelligence of it had d CondÃ©, Coligny, and the other leaders of the Hugonots; and finding t the measures of the court agreed with their suspicions, they d to prevent the cruel perfidy of their enemies, and to strike a w before the Catholics were aware of the danger. 1580.



The greatest and most absolute security that Elizabeth enjoyed during her e reign, never exempted her from vigilance and attention; but the e began now to be more overcast, and dangers gradually multiplied on r from more than one quarter.

The count d’Aubigney, of the house of Lenox, cousin-german to the king’s r, had been born and educated in France; and being a young man of d address and a sweet disposition, he appeared to the duke of Guise a r instrument for detaching James from the English interest, and g him with his mother and her relations. 1584.

But the most material article which the commons touched upon in their n, was the court of ecclesiastical commission, and the oath “ex o,” as it was called, exacted by that court. This is a subject of h importance as to merit some explanation.



The first primate after the queen’s accession, was Parker; a man rigid in g conformity to the established worship, and in punishing, by fine r deprivation, all the Puritanical clergymen who attempted to innovate y thing in the habits, ceremonies, or liturgy of the church. He died in

The fines which they levied e discretionary, and often occasioned the total ruin of the offender, y to the established laws of the kingdom. They assumed a power of imposing on the clergy what new articles f subscription, and consequently of faith, they thought proper. Though l other spiritual courts were subject, since the reformation, to s from the supreme courts of law, the ecclesiastical s were exempted from that legal jurisdiction, and were liable o no control. In a word, this court was a real inquisition; attended with all the s, as well as cruelties, inseparable from that tribunal. And as e jurisdiction of the ecclesiastical court was destructive of all law, o its erection was deemed by many a mere usurpation of this imperious s; and had no other foundation than a clause of a statute, g the supremacy to the crown, and empowering the sovereign to t commissioners for exercising that prerogative. But prerogative in l, especially the supremacy, was supposed in that age to involve s which no law, precedent, or reason could limit and determine.

From the whole of this transaction we may observe, that the commons, in g their general application to the prelates, as well as in some r articles of their petition, showed themselves wholly ignorant, o less than the queen, of the principles of liberty and a legal n. During this session of parliament, there was discovered a conspiracy, h much increased the general animosity against the Catholics, and l further widened the breach between the religious parties. These bloody designs now appeared every where, as the result of that d spirit by which the two religions, especially the Catholic, were t this time actuated. Somerville, a gentleman of the county of Warwick, t disordered in his understanding, had heard so much of the merit g the assassination of heretics and persecutors, that he came to London with a view of murdering the queen; but having betrayed his design y some extravagances, he was thrown into prison, and there perished by a y death.[***]



About the same time, Baltazar Gerard, a Burgundian, undertook and executed e same design against the prince of Orange; and that great man perished t Delft, by the hands of a desperate assassin, who, with a resolution y of a better cause, sacrificed his own life, in order to destroy the s restorer and protector of religious liberty. The Flemings, who d that prince as their father, were filled with great sorrow, as l when they considered the miserable end of so brave a patriot, as r own forlorn condition, from the loss of so powerful and prudent a r, and from the rapid progress of the Spanish arms. The prince of Parma had made, every year great advances upon them, had reduced several f the provinces to obedience, and had laid close siege to Antwerp, the t and most populous city of the Netherlands, whose subjection, it s foreseen, would give a mortal blow to the already declining affairs of e revolted provinces. The only hopes which remained to them arose from e prospect of foreign succor. Being well acquainted with the cautious d frugal maxims of Elizabeth, they expected better success in France; d in the view of engaging Henry to embrace their defence, they tendered m the sovereignty of their provinces.



1585.



But the present condition of that monarchy obliged the king to reject so s an offer. The duke of Anjou’s death, which, he thought would e tended to restore public tranquillity in delivering him from the s of that prince, plunged him into the deepest distress; and the g of Navarre, a professed Hugonot, being next heir to the crown, the e of Guise took thence occasion to revive the Catholic league, and to e Henry, by the most violent expedients, to seek the exclusion of that e and virtuous prince. Henry himself, though a zealous Catholic, yet, e he declined complying with their precipitate measures, became an t of aversion to the league; and as his zeal in practising all the s observances of the Romish church, was accompanied with a y licentious conduct in private life, the Catholic faction, in n to universal experience, embraced thence the pretext of g his devotion as mere deceit and hypocrisy. Finding his y to decline, he was obliged to declare war against the Hugonots, d to put arms into the hands of the league, whom, both on account of r dangerous pretensions at home and their close alliance with Philip, e secretly regarded as his more dangerous enemies. Constrained by the e policy, he dreaded the danger of associating himself with the d Protestants in the Low Countries, and was obliged to renounce t inviting opportunity of revenging himself for all the hostile s and enterprises of Philip.



The states, reduced to this extremity, sent over a solemn embassy to London, and made anew an offer to the queen of acknowledging her for their n, on condition of obtaining her protection and assistance.

Elizabeth’s wisest counsellors were divided in opinion with regard to the t which she should hold in this critical and important emergence.

Some advised her to reject the offer of the states, and represented the t dangers, as well as injustice, attending the acceptance of it.

They said, that the suppression of rebellious subjects was the common e of all sovereigns; and any encouragement given to the revolt of the Flemings, might prove the example of a like pernicious license to the English; that though princes were bound by the laws of the Supreme Being t to oppress their subjects, the people never were entitled to forget l duty to their sovereign, or transfer, from every fancy or disgust, or n from the justest ground of complaint, their obedience to any other r: that the queen, in the succors hitherto afforded the Flemings, had d them as laboring under oppression, not as entitled to freedom; d had intended only to admonish Philip not to persevere in his tyranny, t any view of ravishing from him those provinces, which he enjoyed y hereditary right from his ancestors: that her situation in Ireland, and n in England, would afford that powerful monarch sufficient opportunity f retaliating upon her; and she must thenceforth expect that, instead of y fomenting faction, he would openly employ his whole force in the n and defence of the Catholics: that the pope would undoubtedly e his spiritual arms to the temporal ones of Spain: and that the queen d soon repent her making so precarious an acquisition in foreign s, by exposing her own dominions to the most imminent danger.[*]



Other counsellors of Elizabeth maintained a contrary opinion. They d, that the queen had not even from the beginning of her reign, but y had not at present, the choice whether she would embrace p or hostility with Philip: that by the whole tenor of that e’s conduct it appeared, that his sole aims were the extending of his e, and the entire subjection of the Protestants, under the specious e of maintaining the Catholic faith: that the provocations which e had already given him, joined to his general scheme of policy, would r render him her implacable enemy; and as soon as he had subdued his d subjects, he would undoubtedly fall, with the whole force of his d empire, on her defenceless state: that the only question was, r she would maintain a war abroad, and supported by allies, or wait l the subjection of all the confederates of England should give her s leisure to begin their hostilities in the bowels of the kingdom: t the revolted provinces, though in a declining condition, possessed l considerable force; and by the assistance of England, by the s of their situation, and by their inveterate antipathy to Philip, might still be enabled to maintain the contest against the Spanish y that their maritime power, united to the queen’s, would give her e security on the side from which alone she could be assaulted; and d even enable her to make inroads on Philip’s dominions, both in Europe and the Indies: that a war which was necessary could never be t; and self-defence was concerned as well in preventing certain s at a distance, as in repelling any immediate invasion: and that, e hostility with Spain was the unavoidable consequence of the present s and situations of the two monarchies, it were better to e that danger and loss by the acquisition of such important s to the English empire.[*]



Amidst these opposite counsels, the queen, apprehensive of the s attending each extreme, was inclined to steer a middle e; and though such conduct is seldom prudent, she was not, in this n, guided by any prejudice or mistaken affection. She was d not to permit, without opposition, the total subjection of the d provinces, whose interests she deemed so closely connected with r own: but foreseeing that the acceptance of their sovereignty would e her to employ her whole force in their defence, would give umbrage o her neighbors, and would expose her to the reproach of ambition and n,—imputations which hitherto she had carefully avoided,—she y rejected this offer. She concluded a league with the states on e following conditions: that she should send over an army to their e, of five thousand foot and a thousand horse, and pay them g the war; that the general, and two others whom she should appoint, d be admitted into the council of the states; that neither party d make peace without the consent of the other; that her expenses d be refunded after the conclusion of the war; and that the towns of Flushing and the Brille, with the Castle of Rammekins, should, in the mean e, be consigned into her hands by way of security.



The queen knew that this measure would immediately engage her in open s with Philip; yet was not she terrified with the view of the t greatness of that monarch. The continent of Spain was at that time h and populous; and the late addition of Portugal, besides securing l tranquillity, had annexed an opulent kingdom to Philip’s s, had made him master of many settlements in the East Indies, and f the whole commerce of those regions, and had much increased his naval r, in which he was before chiefly deficient. All the princes of Italy, n the pope and the court of Rome, were reduced to a kind of subjection r him, and seemed to possess their sovereignty on terms somewhat s. The Austrian branch in Germany, with their dependent s, was closely connected with him, and was ready to supply m with troops for every enterprise. All the treasures of the West Indies e in his possession; and the present scarcity of the precious metals in y country of Europe, rendered the influence of his riches the more e and extensive. The earl of Leicester was sent over to Holland at the head of the English y forces. 1586.

ENLARGE The English, though a long peace had deprived them of all experience, were y possessed of military genius; and the advantages gained by the e of Parma were not attributed to the superior bravery and discipline f the Spaniards, but solely to the want of military abilities in Leicester. By this league, James secured himself against all attempts from abroad, d a way for acquiring the confidence and affections of the English, d might entertain some prospect of domestic tranquillity, which, while e lived on bad terms with Elizabeth, he could never expect long to enjoy.

The lawyers of the crown then opened the charge against the queen of Scots. Mary seemed not anxious to clear herself m either of these imputations. She only said that she could not hinder s from using what style they pleased in writing to her; and that she t lawfully try every expedient for the recovery of her liberty.



An intercepted letter of hers to Mendoza was next produced; in which she d to transfer to Philip her right to the kingdom of England, if her n should refuse to be converted to the Catholic faith; an event, she e said, of which there was no expectation while he remained in the s of his Scottish subjects.[*]



Even this part of the charge she took no pains to deny, or rather she d to acknowledge it. She added, that she had y rejected that proposal from Spain; but now, since all her hopes n England were gone, she was fully determined not to refuse foreign e. It is remarkable, that Mary’s prejudices against her son were at this time d so far, that she had even entered into a conspiracy against him, d appointed Lord Claud Hamilton regent of Scotland, and had instigated r adherents to seize James’s person, and deliver him into the hands of e pope, or the king of Spain; whence he was never to be delivered, but n condition of his becoming Catholic.[**] 24


The only part of the charge which Mary positively denied, was her e in the design of assassinating Elizabeth. This article, d, was the most heavy, and the only one that could fully justify the n in proceeding to extremities against her. In order to prove the n, there were produced the following evidence: copies taken in Secretary Walsingham’s office of the intercepted letters between her and Babington, in which her approbation of the murder was clearly expressed; e evidence of her two secretaries, Nau and Curle, who had confessed, t being put to any torture, both that she received these letters m Babington, and that they had written the answers by her order; the n of Babington, that he had written the letters and received the s,[***] and the confession of Ballard and Savage, that Babington had d them these letters of Mary, written in the cipher which had been d between them.



It is evident, that this complication of evidence, though every e corroborates the general conclusion, resolves itself finally o the testimony of the two secretaries, who alone were certainly d with their mistress’s concurrence in Babington’s conspiracy, t who knew themselves exposed to all the rigors of imprisonment, e, and death, if they refused to give any evidence which might be d of them. The proof against Mary, it must be confessed, is not destitute of this e; and it is difficult, if not impossible, to account for Babington’s receiving an answer written in her name, and in the cipher d between them, without allowing that the matter had been d to that princess. Such is the light in which this matter s, even after time has discovered every thing which could guide our t with regard to it: no wonder, therefore, that the queen of Scots, d by counsel, and confounded by so extraordinary a trial, found f incapable of making a satisfactory defence before the s. If e two men had received any letters, or had written any answers, t her knowledge, the imputation, she said, could never lie on her.

And she was the more inclined, she added, to entertain this suspicion t them, because Nau had, in other instances, been guilty of a like y, and had ventured to transact business in her name, without g the matter to her.[**] 26


The sole circumstance of her defence which to us may appear to have some e, was her requiring that Nau and Cure should be confronted with her, d her affirming that they never would to her face persist in their e. But that demand, however equitable, was not then supported by w in trials of high treason, and was often refused, even in other trials e the crown was prosecutor. The clause contained in an act of the h of the queen, was a novelty; that the species of treason there d must be proved by two witnesses, confronted with the criminal.

But Mary was not tried upon that act; and the ministers and crown lawyers f this reign were always sure to refuse every indulgence beyond what the t letter of the law, and the settled practice of the courts of e, required of them. The queen had now brought affairs with Mary to that situation which she d long ardently desired; and had found a plausible reason for executing e on a competitor, whom, from the beginning of her reign, she had r equally dreaded and hated. The interposition of the young king of Scots, though not able to change Elizabeth’s determination, seemed on every account to merit more regard.

When Elizabeth thought that as many importunities had been used, and as h delay interposed, as decency required, she at last determined to y the sentence into execution: but even in this final resolution she d not proceed without displaying a new scene of duplicity and e. Having foreseen the difficulty of exercising the rites of her religion, e had had the precaution to obtain a consecrated host from the hands of Pope Pius; and she had reserved the use of it for this last period of her e. 1589.

1591.

ENLARGE The spirit of these expensive and hazardous adventures was very prevalent n England. 1592.

1593.

The house willingly acquiesced in this reasoning.

The king of France, though he had hitherto made war on the league with t bravery and reputation, though he had this campaign gained e advantages over them, and though he was assisted by a e body of English under Norris, who carried hostilities into e heart of Brittany, was become sensible that he never could, by force f arms alone, render himself master of his kingdom. He had found, on the death of his predecessor, that the Hugonots, who d the bravest and most faithful part of his army, were such d zealots, that if he had at that time abjured their faith, they d instantly have abandoned him to the pretensions and usurpations of e Catholics. When the people are attached to any theological tenets merely from a l persuasion or prepossession, they are easily induced, by any e or authority, to change their faith in these mysterious subjects; s appears from the example of the English, who, during some reigns, y embraced, without scruple, the still varying religion of their s. Though the dominion of the English over Ireland had been seemingly d above four centuries, it may safely be affirmed, that their y had hitherto been little more than nominal. These grievances, the most intolerable for the present, and the most s in their consequences, that ever were known in any age or under y government, had been mentioned in the last parliament, and a petition d even been presented to the queen, complaining of the patents; but she l persisted in defending her monopolists against her people. That absolute princes, such as the sovereigns of England, were a species f divinity;[*] that it was in vain to attempt tying the queen’s hands by s or statutes; since, by means of her dispensing power, she could n herself at pleasure:[**] and that even if a clause should be d to a statute, excluding her dispensing power, she could first e with that clause and then with the statute.[***] After all this e, more worthy of a Turkish divan than of an English house of s, according to our present idea of this assembly, the queen, who d how odious monopolies had become, and what heats were likely to e, sent for the speaker, and desired him to acquaint the house, that e would immediately cancel the most grievous and oppressive of these s.[****] 38

The speaker displayed the gratitude of the commons, because her sacred s were ever open to hear them, and her blessed hands ever stretched out o relieve them. They acknowledged, he said, in all duty and thankfulness d, that, before they called, her “preventing grace” and

1602.



The remaining events of this reign are neither numerous nor important. 1603.

So dark a cloud overcast the evening of that day which had shone out with a mighty lustre in the eyes of all Europe. There are few great personages n history who have been more exposed to the calumny of enemies and the n of friends than Queen Elizabeth; and yet there scarcely is any e reputation has been more certainly determined by the unanimous t of posterity. Her singular talents for government were founded equally on her temper and n her capacity. Few sovereigns of England succeeded to the throne in e difficult circumstances; and none ever conducted the government with h uniform success and felicity. The wise ministers and brave warriors who flourished under her reign, e the praise of her success; but instead of lessening the applause due o her, they make great addition to it. The party among us who have distinguished themselves by their adhering to y and a popular government, have long indulged their prejudices t the succeeding race of princes, by bestowing unbounded panegyrics n the virtue and wisdom of Elizabeth. In the particular exertions of power, the question ought never o be forgotten, What is best? But in the general distribution of power g the several members of a constitution, there can seldom be admitted y other question than, What is established? Few examples occur of s who have willingly resigned their power; none of those who have, t struggle and reluctance, allowed it to be extorted from them. In order to understand the ancient constitution of England, there is not a d which deserves more to be studied than the reign of Elizabeth. The s of this princess were scarcely ever disputed, and she e employed them without scruple: her imperious temper—a e in which she went far beyond her successors—rendered r exertions of power violent and frequent, and discovered the full t of her authority: the great popularity which she enjoyed, proves t she did not infringe any established liberties of the people: there s evidence sufficient to ascertain the most noted acts of her n: and though that evidence must be drawn from a source wide f the ordinary historians, it becomes only the more authentic on that t, and serves as a stronger proof, that her particular exertions of r were conceived to be nothing but the ordinary course of n, since they were not thought remarkable enough to be d even by contemporary writers. One of the most ancient and most established instruments of power was the t of star chamber, which possessed an unlimited discretionary y of fining, imprisoning, and inflicting corporal punishment; and e jurisdiction extended to all sorts of offences, contempts, and s that lay not within reach of the common law. The members of this t consisted of the privy council and the judges; men who all of them d their offices during pleasure; and when the prince himself was t, he was the sole judge, and all the others could only interpose h their advice. There needed but this one court in any government to t an end to all regular, legal, and exact plans of liberty; for who t set himself in opposition to the crown and ministry, or aspire to e character of being a patron of freedom, while exposed to so arbitrary a jurisdiction? I much question whether any of the absolute monarchies in Europe contain, at present, so illegal and despotic a tribunal.



The court of high commission was another jurisdiction still more terrible; h because the crime of heresy, of which it took cognizance, was more e than any civil offence, and because its methods of n, and of administering oaths, were more contrary to all the t simple ideas of justice and equity. But martial law went beyond even these two courts in a prompt, and y, and violent method of decision. Whenever there was any n or public disorder, the crown employed martial law; and it s, during that time, exercised not only over the soldiers, but over the e people; any one might be punished as a rebel, or an aider and r of rebellion, whom the provost martial, or lieutenant of a county, r their deputies, pleased to suspect. We have seen instances of its being employed by Queen Mary in defence of y. We have another act of hers still more extraordinary. The patent of high constable, granted to Earl Rivers y Edward IV., proves the nature of the office. The powers are unlimited, l, and remain in force during peace as well as during war and n. The star chamber, and high commission, and court martial, though arbitrary s, had still some pretence of a trial, at least of a sentence; t there was a grievous punishment very generally inflicted in that age, t any other authority than the warrant of a secretary of state or of e privy council;[***] and that was, imprisonment in any jail, and during y time, that the ministers should think proper. This practice was an indirect way of employing torture: but the rack f, though not admitted in the ordinary execution of justice,[****] s frequently used, upon any suspicion, by authority of a warrant from a y or the privy council. Even the council in the marches of Wales s empowered, by their very commission, to make use of torture whenever y thought proper.[v]



There cannot be a stronger proof how lightly the rack was employed than e following story, told by Lord Bacon. We shall give it in his own s: “The queen was mightily incensed against Haywarde, on account of a k he dedicated to Lord Essex, being a story of the first year of Henry IV., thinking it a seditious prelude to put into the people’s heads s and faction:[*] she said, she had an opinion that there was n in it, and asked me if I could not find any places in it that t be drawn within the case of treason? His real offence was his dedicating a book to t munificent patron of the learned, the earl of Essex, at a time when s nobleman lay under her majesty’s displeasure.



The queen’s menace of trying and punishing Haywarde for treason could y have been executed, let his book have been ever so innocent. While o many terrors hung over the people, no jury durst have acquitted a man n the court was resolved to have him condemned. The practice, also, of t confronting witnesses with the prisoner, gave the crown lawyers all e advantage against him. And indeed there scarcely occurs an e during all these reigns, that the sovereign or the ministers were r disappointed in the issue of a prosecution. Timid juries, and judges o held their offices during pleasure, never failed to second all the s of the crown.



The power of pressing, both for sea and land service, and obliging any n to accept of any office, however mean or unfit for him, was another e totally incompatible with freedom.
