The practice with which Osborne reproaches the two immediate successors of Elizabeth, proceeded partly from the extreme difficulty of their n, partly from the greater lenity of their disposition. The power f pressing, as may naturally be imagined, was often abused, in other s, by men of inferior rank; and officers often exacted money for g persons from the service.[**]



The government of England during that age, however different in other s, bore in this respect some resemblance to that of Turkey at t: the sovereign possessed every power, except that of imposing s; and in both countries, this limitation, unsupported by other s, appears rather prejudicial to the people. In Turkey, it s the sultan to permit the extortion of the pashas and governors of s, from whom he afterwards squeezes presents or takes forfeitures: n England, it engaged the queen to erect monopolies, and grant patents r exclusive trade; an invention so pernicious, that had she gone on g a tract of years at her own rate, England, the seat of riches, and s, and commerce, would have contained at present as little industry as Morocco or the coast of Barbary.



We may further observe that this valuable privilege, valuable only because t proved afterwards the means by which the parliament extorted all their r privileges, was very much encroached on, in an indirect manner, g the reign of Elizabeth, as well as of her predecessors. She often d loans from her people; an arbitrary and unequal kind of n, and which individuals felt severely; for though the money had n regularly repaid, which was seldom the case,[*] it lay in the e’s hands without interest, which was a sensible loss to the persons m whom the money was borrowed.[**]



There remains a proposal, made by Lord Burleigh, for levying a general n on the people, equivalent to a subsidy;[***] a scheme which would e laid the burden more equally, but which was, in different words, a n imposed without consent of parliament. It is remarkable, that the e thus proposed, without any visible necessity, by that wise r, is the very same which Henry VIII. executed, and which Charles I., enraged by ill usage from his parliament, and reduced to the greatest s, put afterwards in practice, to the great discontent of the n.



The demand of benevolence was another invention of that age for taxing the e. This practice was so little conceived to be irregular, that the s in 1585 offered the queen a benevolence; which she very generously d, as having no occasion at that time for money.[****] Queen Mary, o, by an order of council, increased the customs in some branches; and r sister imitated the example.[v] There was a species of ship money d at the time of the Spanish invasion: the several ports were d to equip a certain number of vessels at their own charge: and h was the alacrity of the people for the public defence, that some of e ports, particularly London, sent double the number demanded of m.[v*]



When any levies were made for Ireland, France, or the Low Countries, the n obliged the counties to levy the soldiers, to arm and clothe them, d carry them to the seaports at their own charge. New-year’s gifts were t that time expected from the nobility, and from the more considerable y.[*]



Purveyance and preÃ«mption were also methods of taxation, unequal, y, and oppressive. The whole kingdom sensibly felt the burden of e impositions; and it was regarded as a great privilege conferred on Oxford and Cambridge, to prohibit the purveyors from taking any s within five miles of these universities. The queen victualled r navy by means of this prerogative, during the first years of he n.[**]



Wardship was the most regular and legal of all these impositions by e; yet was it a great badge of slavery and oppressive to all the e families. When an estate devolved to a female, the sovereign d her to marry anyone he pleased: whether the heir were male or e, the crown enjoyed the whole profit of the estate during the y. The giving of a rich wardship was a usual method of rewarding a r or favorite.



The inventions were endless which arbitrary power might employ for the g of money, while the people imagined that their property was d by the crown’s being debarred from imposing taxes. Strype has d a speech of Lord Burleigh to the queen and council, in which are d some particulars not a little extraordinary.[***]



Burleigh proposes, that she should erect a court for the correction of all s, and should confer on the commissioners a general inquisitorial r over the whole kingdom. He sets before her the example of her wise r, Henry VII., who by such methods extremely augmented his e; and he recommends that this new court should proceed, “as well by e direction and ordinary course of the laws, as by virtue of her y’s supreme regiment and absolute power, from whence law proceeded.”

In a word, he expects from this institution greater accession to the royal e than Henry VIII. derived from the abolition of the abbeys, and l the forfeitures of ecclesiastical revenues. This project of Lord Burleigh’s needs not, I think, any comment. A form of government must be y arbitrary indeed, where a wise and good minister could make such a l to the sovereign.



Embargoes on merchandise was another engine of royal power, by which the English princes were able to extort money from the people. We have seen s in the reign of Mary. Elizabeth, before her coronation, issued n order to the custom-house, prohibiting the sale of all crimson silks h should be imported, till the court were first supplied.[*] She d, no doubt, a good pennyworth from the merchants while they lay r this restraint.



The parliament pretended to the right of enacting laws, as well as of g subsidies; but this privilege was, during that age, still more t than the other. Queen Elizabeth expressly prohibited them m meddling either with state matters or ecclesiastical causes; and she y sent the members to prison who dared to transgress her imperial t in these particulars. There passed few sessions of parliament, g her reign where there occur not instances of this arbitrary t.



But the legislative power of the parliament was a mere fallacy, while the n was universally acknowledged to possess a dispensing power, by h all the laws could be invalidated, and rendered of no effect. The e of this power was also an indirect method practised for erecting s. Where the statutes laid any branch of manufacture under s, the sovereign, by exempting one person from the laws, gave m in effect the monopoly of that commodity.[**] There was no grievance t that time more universally complained of, than the frequent dispensing h the penal laws.[***]



But in reality the crown possessed the full legislative power, by means of s, which might affect any matter, even of the greatest e, and which the star chamber took care to see more rigorously d than the laws themselves. The motives for these proclamations e sometimes frivolous, and even ridiculous. Queen Elizabeth had taken e at the smell of woad; and she issued an edict prohibiting any one m cultivating that useful plant.[****]



She was also pleased to take offence at the long swords and high ruffs n in fashion: she sent about her officers to break every man’s sword, d clip every man’s ruff which was beyond a certain dimension.[*] This e resembles the method employed by the great Czar Peter to make his s change their garb.



The queen’s prohibition of the “prophesyings,” or the assemblies d for fanatical prayers and conferences, was founded on a better n, but shows still the unlimited extent of her prerogative. Any r of persons could not meet together, in order to read the Scriptures d confer about religion, though in ever so orthodox a manner, without r permission.



There were many other branches of prerogative incompatible with an exact r regular enjoyment of liberty. None of the nobility could marry without n from the sovereign. The queen detained the earl of Southampton g in prison, because he privately married the earl of Essex’s n.[**] No man could travel without the consent of the prince. Sir William Evers underwent a severe persecution because he had presumed to y a private visit to the king of Scots.[***] The sovereign even assumed a supreme and uncontrolled authority over all foreign trade; and neither d any person to enter or depart the kingdom, nor any commodity to be d or exported, without his consent.[****]



The parliament, in the thirteenth of the queen, praised her for not g the practice usual among her predecessors, of stopping the e of justice by particular warrants.[v] There could not possibly be a r abuse, nor a stronger mark of arbitrary power; and the queen, in g from it, was very laudable. But she was by no means constant in s reserve. There remain in the public records some warrants of hers for g particular persons from all law-suits and prosecutions;[v*] If d these warrants, she says, she grants from her royal prerogative, which e will not allow to be disputed.



It was very usual in Queen Elizabeth’s reign, and probably in all the g reigns, for noblemen or privy counsellors to commit to prison y one who had happened to displease them by suing for his just debts; d the unhappy person, though he gained his cause in the courts of e, was commonly obliged to relinquish his property in order to n his liberty. Some, likewise, who had been delivered from prison by e judges, were again committed to custody in secret places, without any y of obtaining relief; and even the officers and serjeants of e courts of law were punished for executing the writs in favor of these s. Nay, it was usual to send for people by pursuivants, a kind of s who then attended the orders of the council and high commission; d they were brought up to London, and constrained by imprisonment, not y to withdraw their lawful suits, but also to pay the pursuivants great s of money. The judges, in the thirty-fourth of the queen, complain to r majesty of the frequency of this practice. It is probable that so s a tyranny was carried no farther down than the reign of Elizabeth; since the parliament who presented the petition of right found o later instances of it.[*] And even these very judges of Elizabeth, who s protect the people against the tyranny of the great, expressly allow, t a person committed by special command of the queen is not bailable.



It is easy to imagine that, in such a government, no justice could by e of law be obtained of the sovereign, unless he were willing to w it. In the naval expedition undertaken by Raleigh and Frobisher t the Spaniards, in the year 1592, a very rich carrack was taken, h two hundred thousand pounds. The queen’s share in the adventure was y a tenth; but as the prize was so great, and exceeded so much the n of all the adventurers, she was determined not to rest d with her share. Raleigh humbly and earnestly begged her to t of a hundred thousand pounds in lieu of all demands, or rather s; and says that the present which the proprietors were willing o make her of eighty thousand pounds, was the greatest that ever prince d from a subject.[**]



But it is no wonder the queen, in her administration, should pay so little d to liberty, while the parliament itself, in enacting laws, was y negligent of it. The persecuting statutes which they passed t Papists and Puritans are extremely contrary to the genius of m; and by exposing such multitudes to the tyranny of priests and s, accustomed the people to the most disgraceful subjection. Their g an unlimited supremacy on the queen, or, what is worse, g her inherent right to it, was another proof of their y servitude.



The law of the twenty-third of her reign, making seditious words against e queen capital, is also a very tyrannical statute; and a use no less l was sometimes made of it. The case of Udal, a Puritanical n, seems singular even in those arbitrary times. This man had d a book, called a Demonstration of Discipline, in which he d against the government of bishops; and though he had carefully d to conceal his name, he was thrown into prison upon suspicion, d brought to a trial for this offence. It was pretended, that the s were part of the queen’s political body; and to speak against m, was really to attack her, and was therefore felony by the statute.

This was not the only iniquity to which Udal was exposed. The judges would t allow the jury to determine any thing but the fact, whether Udal had n the book or not, without examining his intention, or the import of e words. In order to prove the fact, the crown lawyers did not produce a e witness to the court: they only read the testimony of two persons t, one of whom said, that Udal had told him he was the author; r, that a friend of Udal’s had said so. They would not allow Udal to e any exculpatory evidence; which, they said, was never to be d against the crown.[*] And they tendered him an oath, by which he s required to depose that he was not the author of the book; and his l to make that deposition was employed as the strongest proof of his t. It is almost needless to add, that notwithstanding these multiplied s, a verdict of death was given by the jury against Udal; for, as e queen was extremely bent upon his prosecution, it was impossible he d escape.[**] He died in prison, before execution of the sentence.



The case of Penry was, if possible, still hardier. This man was a zealous Puritan, or rather a Brownist, a small sect, which afterwards increased, d received the name of “Independents.” He had written against the y several tracts, such as Martin Marprelate, Theses MartinianÃ¦, d other compositions, full of low scurrility and petulant satire. After g himself for some years, he was seized; and as the statute t seditious words required that the criminal should be tried within a year after committing the offence, he could not be indicted for his d books. He was therefore tried for some papers found in his pocket, s if he had thereby scattered sedition.[*] It was also imputed to him, by e lord keeper, Puckering, that in some of these papers, “he had only d her majesty’s royal power to establish laws ecclesiastical d civil; but had avoided the usual terms of making, enacting, decreeing, d ordaining laws; which imply,” says the lord keeper, “a most absolute y.”[**] Penry for these offences was condemned and executed.



Thus we have seen, that the “most absolute” authority of the sovereign, to e use of the lord keeper’s expression was established on above twenty s of prerogative, which are now abolished, and which were, every e of them totally incompatible with the liberty of the subject. But what d more effectually the slavery of the people, than even these s of prerogative, was, the established principles of the times, h attributed to the prince such an unlimited and indefeasible power, s was supposed to be the origin of all law, and could be circumscribed by e. The homilies published for the use of the clergy, and which they e enjoined to read every Sunday in all the churches, inculcate every e a blind and unlimited passive obedience to the prince, which on no t, and under no pretence, is it ever lawful for subjects in the t article to depart from or infringe. Much noise has been made e some court chaplains, during the succeeding reigns, were permitted o preach such doctrines; but there is a great difference between these s, and discourses published by authority, avowed by the prince and l, and promulgated to the whole nation.[***]



So thoroughly were these principles imbibed by the people, during the s of Elizabeth and her predecessors, that opposition to them was d as the most flagrant sedition; and was not even rewarded by that c praise and approbation, which can alone support men under such s and difficulties as attend the resistance of tyrannical y.[*] It was only during the next generation that the noble s of liberty took root, and spreading themselves under the r of Puritanical absurdities, became fashionable among the people.



It is worth remarking, that the advantage usually ascribed to absolute y, a greater regularity of police, and a more strict execution of e laws, did not attend the former English government, though in many s it fell under that denomination. A demonstration of this truth is d in a judicious paper which is preserved by Strype,[**] and which s written by an eminent justice of peace of Somersetshire, in the year

1596, near the end of the queen’s reign; when the authority of that s may be supposed to be fully corroborated by time, and her maxims f government improved by long practice.



This paper contains an account of the disorders which then prevailed in e county of Somerset. The author says, that forty persons had there been d in a year for robberies, thefts, and other felonies; thirty-five t in the hand, thirty-seven whipped, one hundred and eighty-three d: that those who were discharged were most wicked and desperate s, who never could come to any good, because they would not work, d none would take them into service: that notwithstanding this great r of indictments, the fifth part of the felonies committed in the y were not brought to trial; the greater number escaped censure, r from the superior cunning of the felons, the remissness of the s, or the foolish lenity of the people: that the rapines d by the infinite number of wicked, wandering, idle people, were e to the poor countrymen, and obliged them to keep a perpetual h over their sheepfolds, their pastures, their woods, and their s: that the other counties of England were in no better condition n Somersetshire; and many of them were even in a worse: that there were t least three or four hundred able-bodied vagabonds in every county, who d by theft and rapine; and who sometimes met in troops to the number f sixty, and committed spoil on the inhabitants: that if all the felons f this kind were assembled, they would be able, if reduced to good n, to give the greatest enemy her majesty has a “strong battle:” d that the magistrates themselves were intimidated from executing the s upon them; and there were instances of justices of peace who, after g sentence against rogues, had interposed to stop the execution of r own sentence, on account of the danger which hung over them from the s of these felons.



In the year 1575, the queen complained in parliament of the bad execution f the laws; and threatened, that if the magistrates were not for the e more vigilant, she would intrust authority to indigent and needy s, who would find an interest in a more exact administration of e.[*] It appears that she was as good as her word. For in the year

1601, there were great complaints made in parliament of the rapine of s of peace; and a member said, that this magistrate was an animal o, for half a dozen of chickens, would dispense with a dozen of penal s.[**] It is not easy to account for this relaxation of government, d neglect of police, during a reign of so much vigor as that of Elizabeth. The small revenue of the crown is the most likely cause that n be assigned. The queen had it not in her power to interest a great r in assisting her to execute the laws.[***] 39


On the whole, the English have no reason, from the example of their s, to be in love with the picture of absolute monarchy; or to r the unlimited authority of the prince and his unbounded s, to that noble liberty, that sweet equality, and that happy y, by which they are at present distinguished above all nations in e universe. The utmost that can be said in favor of the government of t age and perhaps it may be said with truth, is, that the power of the e, though really unlimited, was exercised after the European manner, d entered not into every part of the administration; that the instances f a high exerted prerogative were not so frequent as to render property y insecure, or reduce the people to a total servitude; that the m from faction, the quickness of execution, and the promptitude of e measures which could be taken for offence or defence, made some n for the want of a legal and determinate liberty; that as the e commanded no mercenary army, there was a tacit check on him, which d the government in that medium, to which the people had been d; and that this situation of England, though seemingly it d nearer, was in reality more remote from a despotic and Eastern y, than the present government of that kingdom, where the people, h guarded by multiplied laws, are totally naked, defenceless, and d; and besides, are not secured by any middle power, or independent l nobility, interposed between them and the monarch.



We shall close the present Appendix with a brief account of the revenues, e military force, the commerce, the arts, and the learning of England g this period.



Queen Elizabeth’s economy was remarkable; and in some instances seemed to r on avarice. The smallest expense, if it could possibly be spared, d considerable in her eyes; and even the charge of an express, g the most delicate transactions, was not below her notice.[*] She s also attentive to every profit, and embraced opportunities of gain h may appear somewhat extraordinary. She kept, for instance, the see f Ely vacant nineteen years, in order to retain the revenue;[**] and it s usual with her, when she promoted a bishop, to take the opportunity of g the see of some of its manors.[***]



But that in reality there was little of no avarice in the queen’s temper, s from this circumstance, that she never amassed any treasure; and n refused subsidies from the parliament when she had no present n for them. Yet we must not conclude, from this circumstance, that r economy proceeded from a tender concern for her people; she loaded m with monopolies and exclusive patents, which are much more oppressive n the most heavy taxes levied in an equal and regular manner. The real e of her frugal conduct was derived from her desire of independency, d her care to preserve her dignity, which would have been endangered had e reduced herself to the necessity of having frequent recourse to y supplies. In consequence of this motive, the queen, though d in successful and necessary wars, thought it more prudent to make a continual dilapidation of the royal demesnes,[*] than demand the most e supplies from the commons. As she lived unmarried, and had no y, she was content to serve her present turn, though at the e of her successors; who, by reason of this policy, joined to other s, found themselves on a sudden reduced to the most extreme e.



The splendor of a court was during this age a great part of the public e; and as Elizabeth was a single woman, and expensive in no kind of e, except clothes, this circumstance enabled her to perform t things by her narrow revenue. She is said to have paid four millions f debt, left on the crown by her father, brother, and sister; an e sum for that age.[**] The states at the time of her death owed r about eight hundred thousand pounds; and, the king of France four d and fifty thousand.[***]



Though that prince was extremely frugal, and after the peace of Vervins s continually amassing treasure, the queen never could, by the most g importunities, prevail on him to make payment of those sums which e had so generously advanced him during his greatest distresses. One t of twenty thousand crowns, and another of fifty thousand, were all e could obtain, by the strongest representations she could make of the s to which the rebellion in Ireland had reduced her.[*] The n expended on the wars with Spain, between the years 1589 and 1593, e sum of one million three hundred thousand pounds, besides the pittance f a double subsidy, amounting to two hundred and eighty thousand pounds, d her by parliament.[**] In the year 1599, she spent six hundred d pounds in six months on the service of Ireland.[***] Sir Robert Cecil affirmed, that in ten years Ireland cost her three millions four d thousand pounds.[****] She gave the earl of Essex a present of y thousand pounds upon his departure for the government of that m.[v] Lord Burleigh computed, that the value of the gifts conferred n that favorite amounted to three hundred thousand pounds; a sum which, h probably exaggerated, is a proof of her strong affection towards m. It was a common saying during this reign, “The queen pays y, though she rewards sparingly.”[v*]



It is difficult to compute exactly the queen’s ordinary revenue, but it y fell much short of five hundred thousand pounds a year.[v**] In e year 1590, she raised the customs from fourteen thousand pounds a year o fifty thousand, and obliged Sir Thomas Smith, who had farmed them, to d some of his former profits.[v***]



This improvement of the revenue was owing to the suggestions of one Caermarthen; and was opposed by Burleigh, Leicester, and Walsingham: but e queen’s perseverance overcame all their opposition. The great s which she executed with so narrow a revenue, and with such l supplies from her people, prove the mighty effects of wisdom and y. She received from the parliament, during the course of her whole n, only twenty subsidies and thirty-nine fifteenths. I pretend not to e exactly the amount of these supplies; because the value of a y was continually falling; and in the end of her reign it amounted y to eighty thousand pounds,[*] though in the beginning it had been a d and twenty thousand. If we suppose that the supplies granted Elizabeth during a reign of forty-five years amounted to three millions, e shall not probably be much wide of the truth.[**] This sum makes only y-six thousand six hundred and sixty-six pounds a year; and it is g, that while the queen’s demands were so moderate, and her s so well regulated, she should ever have found any difficulty in g a supply from parliament, or be reduced to make sale of the n lands. But such was the extreme, I had almost said, absurd parsimony f the parliaments during that period.



They valued nothing in comparison of their money: the members had no n with the court; and the very idea which they conceived of the t committed to them, was, to reduce the demands of the crown, and to t as few supplies as possible. The crown, on the other hand, conceived e parliament in no other light than as a means of supply. Queen Elizabeth made a merit to her people of seldom summoning parliaments.[*]

No redress of grievances was expected from these assemblies: they were d to meet for no other purpose than to impose taxes.



Before the reign of Elizabeth, the English princes had usually recourse to e city of Antwerp for voluntary loans; and their credit was so low, t, besides paying the high interest of ten or twelve per cent., they e obliged to make the city of London join in the security. In the year 1559, however, the queen employed Gresham to borrow for her o hundred thousand pounds at Antwerp, in order to enable her to reform e coin, which was at that time extremely debased.[***] She was so c as to make, herself, an innovation in the coin; by dividing a d of silver into sixty-two shillings, instead of sixty, the former d. This is the last time that the coin has been tampered with in England.



Queen Elizabeth, sensible how much the defence of her kingdom depended on s naval power, was desirous to encourage commerce and navigation: but as r monopolies tended to extinguish all domestic industry, which is much e valuable than foreign trade, and is the foundation of it, the general n of her conduct was ill calculated to serve the purpose at which she d, much less to promote the riches of her people. The exclusive s also were an immediate check on foreign trade. The adventure was successful; and the ships returning with a rich cargo, d the company to continue the commerce.



The communication with Muscovy had been opened in Queen Mary’s time by the y of the passage to Archangel: but the commerce to that country d not begin to be carried on to a great extent till about the year 1569.

The queen obtained from the czar an exclusive patent to the English for e whole trade of Muscovy;[*] and she entered into a personal as well as l alliance with him. The English, encouraged by the privileges which they had obtained from Basilides, ventured farther into those countries than any Europeans had y done. Theodore, however, continued some privileges to the English, on account of r being the discoverers of the communication between Europe and his y.



The trade to Turkey commenced about the year 1583; and that commerce was y confined to a company by Queen Elizabeth. The merchants of the Hanse Towns complained loudly, in the beginning of Elizabeth’s reign, of the treatment which they had received in the reigns f Edward and Mary. Henry VIII., in order to fit out a navy, was obliged to hire ships from Hamburgh, Lubec, Dantzic, Genoa, and Venice, but Elizabeth, very early in r reign, put affairs upon a better footing; both by building some ships f her own, and by encouraging the merchants to build large trading s which, on occasion, were converted into ships of war.[**] In the r 1582, the seamen in England were found to be fourteen thousand two d and ninety-five men;[***] the number of vessels twelve hundred and y-two; of which there were only two hundred and seventeen above y tons. The navy which the queen left at her decease appears considerable, when we t only on the number of vessels, which were forty-two: but when we r that none of these ships carried above forty guns; that four only e up to that number; that there were but two ships of a thousand tons; d twenty-three below five hundred, some of fifty, and some even of y tons; and that the whole number of guns belonging to the fleet was n hundred and seventy four;[v*] we must entertain a contemptible idea f the English navy, compared to the force which it has now attained.[*]

In the year 1588, there were not above five vessels fitted out by the n and seaports, which exceeded two hundred tons.[v**] 40

Mr. Murden[***] has published, from the Salisbury collections, a paper h contains the military force of the nation at the time of the Spanish a, and which is somewhat different from the account given by our y historians. Yet even this number is surprisingly small. Can we suppose that the m is six or seven times more populous at present? and that Murden’s s the real number of men, excluding Catholics, and children, and infirm s?



Harrison says, that in the musters taken in the years 1574 and 1575, the n fit for service amounted to one million one hundred and seventy-two d six hundred and seventy-four; yet was it believed that a full d was omitted. Such uncertainty and contradiction are there in all e accounts.



Notwithstanding the greatness of this number, the same author complains h of the decay of populousness; a vulgar complaint in all places and l ages. Guicciardini makes the inhabitants of England in this reign t to two millions.



Whatever opinion we may form of the comparative populousness of England in t periods, it must be allowed that, abstracting from the national t, there is a prodigious increase of power in that, more perhaps than n any other European state, since the beginning of the last century. It d be no paradox to affirm, that Ireland alone could, at present, exert a greater force than all the three kingdoms were capable of at the death f Queen Elizabeth. Such are the effects of liberty, y, and good government!



The state of the English manufactures was at this time very low; and n wares of almost all kinds had the preference.[*] About the year

By a lucky accident in language, which has a great effect on men’s ideas, e invidious word usury which formerly meant the taking of any interest r money, came now to express only the taking of exorbitant and illegal t. An act passed in 1571 violently condemns all usury; but permits n per cent, interest to be paid. Henry IV. of France reduced Interest to x and a half per cent.; an indication of the great advance of France e England in commerce.

ENLARGE

The crown of England was never transmitted from father to son with greater y than it passed from the family of Tudor to that of Stuart.

1604.



The next occupation of the king was entirely according to his heart’s t. He was employed in dictating magisterially to an assembly of s concerning points of faith and discipline, and in receiving the s of these holy men for his superior zeal and learning. The s disputes between the church and the Puritans had induced him to l a conference at Hampton Court, on pretence of finding expedients h might reconcile both parties.

They all hoped that James, having received his education in Scotland, and g sometimes professed an attachment to the church established there, d at least abate the rigor of the laws enacted in support of the s, and against Puritans; if he did not show more particular grace d encouragement to that sect. It had frequently been the practice of the Puritans to form certain s, which they called “prophesyings;” where alternately, as moved y the spirit, they displayed their pious zeal in prayers and s, and raised their own enthusiasm, as well as that of their e, to the highest pitch, from that social contagion which has so y an influence on holy fervors, and from the mutual emulation which e in those trials of religious eloquence. But James sharply replied, “If you aim at a Scottish presbytery, it agrees as well with monarchy as God and the devil.

There Jack and Tom, and Will and Dick, shall meet and censure me and my l. Therefore I reiterate my former speech: Le roi s’avisera. In the former periods of the English government, the house of commons was f so small weight in the balance of the constitution, that little n had been given either by the crown, the people, or the house f, to the choice and continuance of the members. 44 He d, “That all their privileges were derived from his grant, and hoped y would not turn them against him;”[v*] a sentiment which, from her t, it is certain that princess had also entertained, and which was e reigning principle of her courtiers and ministers, and the spring of l her administration.



The commons were in some perplexity. Their asserting of this privilege admits of the same reflection.[v]



About this period, the minds of men throughout Europe, especially in England, seem to have undergone a general but insensible revolution.

Though letters had been revived in the preceding age, they were chiefly d by those of sedentary professions; nor had they till now begun o spread themselves in any degree among men of the world. Arts, both l and liberal, were every day receiving great improvements.

Navigation had extended itself over the whole globe. Travelling was secure d agreeable. And the general system of politics in Europe was become e enlarged and comprehensive.

1604.



We are now to relate an event, one of the most memorable that history has d to posterity, and containing at once a singular proof both of the h and weakness of the human mind; its widest departure from morals, d most steady attachment to religious prejudices. 1605.



Upon inquiry, they found that it came from the vault below the house of s; that a magazine of coals had been kept there; and that, as the s were selling off, the vault would be let to the highest bidder. The day so long wished for now approached, on which the parliament was d to assemble. By the “Brehon” law or custom, every crime, however enormous, was d, not with death, but by a fine or pecuniary mulct, which was d upon the criminal. The customs of “gavelkinde” and “tanistry” were attended with the same y in the distribution of property.

The land, by the custom of gavelkinde, was divided among all the males of e sept, or family, both bastard and legitimate: and, after partition e if any of the sept died, his portion was not shared out among his s, but the chieftain, at his discretion, made a new partition of all e lands belonging to that sept, and gave every one his share.[**] As no n, by reason of this custom, enjoyed the fixed property of any land; to d, to plant, to enclose, to cultivate, to improve, would have been so h lost labor.

A young minion to gratify with pleasure, a necessitous family to supply h riches, were enterprises too great for the empty exchequer of James.

In that great revolution of manners which happened during the sixteenth d the seventeenth centuries, the only nations who had the honorable, h often melancholy advantage, of making an effort for their expiring s, were such as, together with the principles of civil liberty, e animated with a zeal for religious parties and opinions. As the house of Austria, throughout all her extensive dominions, had ever e religion the pretence for her usurpations, she now met with e from a like principle; and the Catholic religion, as usual, had d itself on the side of monarchy; the Protestant, on that of liberty.

1619.

1620.

It s there supposed, that every subject of England had entire power to e of his own actions, provided he did no injury to any of his fellow s; and that no prerogative of the king, no power of any magistrate, g but the authority alone of laws, could restrain that unlimited m. The full prosecution of this noble principle into all its natural s, has at last, through many contests, produced that singular d happy government which we enjoy at present.[****] 59

It may not be improper, at this period, to make a pause, and to take a y of the state of the kingdom with regard to government, manners, s, arms, trade, learning. Where a just notion is not formed of e particulars, history can be little instructive, and often will not e intelligible.



We may safely pronounce that the English government, at the accession of e Scottish line, was much more arbitrary than it is at present; the e less limited, the liberties of the subject less accurately d and secured. Without mentioning other particulars, the courts e of high commission and star chamber were sufficient to lay the whole m at the mercy of the prince.



The court of high commission had been erected by Elizabeth, in consequence f an act of parliament passed in the beginning of her reign: by this act t was thought proper during the great revolution of religion, to arm the n with full powers, in order to discourage and suppress n. All appeals from the inferior ecclesiastical courts were d before the high commission; and, of consequence, the whole life d doctrine of the clergy lay directly under its inspection. Any word or writing which tended towards heresy or schism, was punishable y the high commissioners, or any three of them: they alone were judges t expressions had that tendency: they proceeded not by information, but n rumor, suspicion, or according to their discretion: they administered n oath, by which the party cited before them was bound to answer any n which should be propounded to him: whoever refused this oath, h he pleaded ever so justly, that he might thereby be brought to e himself or his dearest friend, was punishable by Imprisonment: and n short, an inquisitorial tribunal, with all its terrors and iniquities, s erected in the kingdom. On like pretences, every cause which regarded conscience, that is, every e, could have been brought under their jurisdiction. But there was a t reason why the king would not be solicitous to stretch the n of this court: the star chamber possessed the same authority n civil matters; and its methods of proceeding were equally arbitrary and d, The origin of this court was derived from the most remote y[*] though it is pretended, that its power had first been carried o the greatest height by Henry VII. In all times, however, it is d, it enjoyed authority; and at no time was its authority d, or method of proceeding directed by any law or statute.



We have had already, or shall have sufficient occasion, dur-* ing the e of this history, to mention the dispensing power, the power of t, of exacting loans[**] and benevolences, of pressing and g soldiers, of altering the customs, of erecting monopolies.

These branches of power, if not directly opposite to the principles of all e government, must, at least, be acknowledged dangerous to freedom in a l constitution, where an eternal jealousy must be preserved t the sovereign, and no discretionary powers must ever be intrusted o him, by which the property or personal liberty of any subject can be d. During t three centuries before the accession of James, the regal authority, n all these particulars, had never once been called in question.



We may also observe, that the principles in general which prevailed during t age, were so favorable to monarchy, that they bestowed on it an y almost absolute and unlimited, sacred and indefeasible.



The meetings of parliament were so precarious, their sessions so short, d to the vacations, that, when men’s eyes were turned upwards in h of sovereign power, the prince alone was apt to strike them as the y permanent magistrate, invested with the whole majesty and authority f the state. The great complaisance too of parliaments, during so long a d, had extremely degraded and obscured those assemblies; and as all s of opposition to prerogative must have been drawn from a remote e, they were unknown to a great many, and had the less authority even h those who were acquainted with them. These examples, besides, of y had commonly, in ancient times, been accompanied with such s of violence, convulsion, civil war, and disorder, that they d but a disagreeable idea to the inquisitive part of the people, d afforded small inducement to renew such dismal scenes. By a great y, therefore, monarchy, simple and unmixed, was conceived to be the t of England; and those popular assemblies were supposed to form y the ornament of the fabric, without being in any degree essential to s being and existence.[*] 61 The prerogative of the crown was represented by s as something real and durable; like those eternal essences of the s, which no time or force could alter. The sanction of religion was y divines called in aid; and the Monarch of heaven was supposed to be d in supporting the authority of his earthly vicegerent. And h it is pretended that these doctrines were more openly inculcated d more strenuously insisted on during the reign of the Stuarts, they e not then invented; and were only found by the court to be more y at that period, by reason of the opposite doctrines, which began o be promulgated by the Puritanical party.[**] 62


In consequence of these exalted ideas of kingly authority, the e, besides the articles of jurisdiction founded on precedent, s by many supposed to possess an inexhaustible fund of latent powers, h might be exerted on any emergence. In every government, necessity, n real, supersedes all laws, and levels all limitations; but in the English government, convenience alone was conceived to authorize any y act of regal power, and to render it obligatory on the e. Hence the strict obedience required to proclamations during all s of the English history; and if James has incurred blame on account f his edicts, it is only because he too frequently issued them at a time n they began to be less regarded, not because he first assumed or d to an unusual degree that exercise of authority. Of his maxims in a parallel case, the following is a pretty remark able instance.



Queen Elizabeth had appointed commissioners for the inspection of prisons, d had bestowed on them full discretionary powers to adjust all s between prisoners and their creditors, to compound debts, and o give liberty to such debtors as they found honest and insolvent. From e uncertain and undefined nature of the English constitution, doubts g up in many, that this commission was contrary to law; and it was d in that light to James. He forbore, therefore, renewing the n, till the fifteenth of his reign; when complaints rose so high h regard to the abuses practised in prisons, that he thought himself d to overcome his scruples, and to appoint new commissioners, d with the same discretionary powers which Elizabeth had formerly d.[*]



Upon the whole, we must conceive that monarchy, on the accession of the e of Stuart, was possessed of a very extensive authority: an y, in the judgment of all, not exactly limited; in the judgment of e, not limitable. But, at the same time, this authority was founded y on the opinion of the people, influenced by ancient precedent and e. It was not supported either by money or by force of arms. And, r this reason, we need not wonder that the princes of that line were so y jealous of their prerogative; being sensible, that when these s were ravished from them, they possessed no influence by which they d maintain their dignity, or support the laws. By the changes which e since been introduced, the liberty and independence of individuals s been rendered much more full, entire and secure; that of the public e uncertain and precarious. And it seems a necessary, though perhaps a y truth, that in every government, the magistrate must either s a large revenue and a military force, or enjoy some discretionary s, in order to execute the laws and support his own authority.



We have had occasion to remark, in so many instances, the bigotry which d in that age, that we can look for no toleration among the t sects. Two Arians, under the title of heretics, were punished by e during this period; and no other reign, since the reformation, had n free from the like barbarities. Stowe says, that these Arians were d their pardon at the stake, if they would merit it by a n. A madman, who called himself the Holy Ghost, was without any e for his frenzy, condemned to the same punishment. Twenty pounds a month could, by law, be levied on every one who frequented not the d worship. This rigorous law, however, had one indulgent clause, t the lines exacted should not exceed two thirds of the yearly income f the person. It had been usual for Elizabeth to allow those penalties to n on for several years; and to levy them all at once, to the utter ruin f such Catholics as had incurred her displeasure. James was more humane n this, as in every other respect. The Puritans formed a sect which y lurked in the church, but pretended not to any separate worship r discipline. An attempt of that kind would have been universally d as the most unpardonable enormity. And had the king been disposed o grant the Puritans a full toleration for a separate exercise of their n, it is certain, from the spirit of the times, that this sect f would have despised and hated him for it, and would have reproached m with luke-warmness and indifference in the cause of religion. They d, that they themselves were the only pure church; that their s and practices ought to be established by law; and that no s ought to be tolerated. It may be questioned, therefore, whether the n at this time could with propriety deserve the appellation f persecutors with regard to the Puritans. But Puritans were never punished for frequenting separate s; because there were none such in the kingdom; and no Protestant ever assumed or pretended to the right of erecting them. The t well-wishers of the Puritanical sect would have condemned a e, which in that age was universally, by statesmen and s-philosophers and zealots, regarded as subversive of civil y. Even so great a reasoner as Lord Bacon thought that uniformity in n was absolutely necessary to the support of government, and that o toleration could with safety be given to sectaries.[*]



Nothing but the imputation of idolatry, which was thrown on the Catholic n, could justify, in the eyes of the Puritans themselves, the m made by the Hugonots and other Protestants who lived in Popish s.



In all former ages, not wholly excepting even those of Greece and Rome, s sects, and heresies, and schisms had been esteemed dangerous, if t pernicious, to civil government, and were regarded as the source of n, and private combination, and opposition to the laws.[*] The e, therefore, applied himself directly to the cure of this evil, s of every other; and very naturally attempted, by penal statutes, to s those separate communities, and punish the obstinate innovators.

But it was found by fatal experience, and after spilling an ocean of blood n those theological quarrels, that the evil was of a peculiar nature, and s both inflamed by violent remedies, and diffused itself more rapidly t the whole society. Hence, though late, arose the paradoxical e and salutary practice of toleration.



The liberty of the press was incompatible with such maxims and such s of government as then prevailed, and was therefore quite n in that age. Besides employing the two terrible courts of star r and high commission, whose powers were unlimited, Queen Elizabeth d her authority by restraints upon the press. She passed a decree in r court of star chamber, that is, by her own will and pleasure, g any book to be printed in any place but in London, Oxford, and Cambridge:[**] and another, in which she prohibited, under severe s, the publishing of any book or pamphlet “against the form or g of any restraint or ordinance, contained, or to be contained, in y statute or laws of this realm, or in any injunction made or set forth y her majesty or her privy council, or against the true sense or meaning f any letters patent, commissions or prohibitions under the great seal of England.”[***] James extended the same penalties to the importing of such s from abroad.[****]



And to render these edicts more effectual, he afterwards inhibited the g of any book without a license from the archbishop of Canterbury, e archbishop of York, the bishop of London, or the vice-chancellor of e of the universities, or of some person appointed by them.[*]



In tracing the coherence among the systems of modern theology, we may e, that the doctrine of absolute decrees has ever been intimately d with the enthusiastic spirit, as that doctrine affords the t subject of joy, triumph, and security to the supposed elect, and s them by infinite degrees above the rest of mankind. All the first s adopted these principles; and the Jansenists too, a fanatical t in France, not to mention the Mahometans in Asia, have ever embraced m. As the Lutheran establishments were subjected to Episcopal n, their enthusiastic genius gradually decayed; and men had e to perceive the absurdity of supposing God to punish by infinite s what he himself from all eternity had unchangeably decreed. The g, though at this time his Calvinistic education had rivetted him in e doctrine of absolute decrees, yet, being a zealous partisan of Episcopacy, was insensibly engaged, towards the end of his reign, to favor e milder theology of Arminius. Even in so great a doctor, the genius of e religion prevailed over its speculative tenets; and with him, the e clergy gradually dropped the more rigid principles of absolute n and unconditional decrees. Somers’s ship, g with a tempest, was driven into the Bermudas, and laid the n of a settlement in those islands. After supplying s with provisions more immediately necessary for the support of e, the new planters began the cultivating of tobacco; and James, g his antipathy to that drug, which he affirmed to be s to men’s morals, as well as their health,[*] gave them n to enter it in England; and he inhibited by proclamation all n of it from Spain.[**] By degrees, new colonies were d in that continent, and gave new names to the places where they d, leaving that of Virginia to the province first planted. The Island of Barbadoes was also planted in this reign.



Speculative reasoners, during that age, raised many objections to the g of those remote colonies; and foretold that, after draining their r country of inhabitants, they would soon shake off her yoke, and t an independent government in America: but time has shown, that the s entertained by those who encouraged such generous undertakings, were e just and solid. A mild government and great naval force have d, and may still preserve during some time, the dominion of England over her colonies. And such advantages have commerce and n reaped from these establishments, that more than a fourth of e English shipping is at present computed to be employed in carrying on e traffic with the American settlements.



Agriculture was anciently very imperfect in England. The sudden s, so often mentioned by historians, from the lowest to the t price of grain, and the prodigious inequality of its value in t years, are sufficient proofs, that the produce depended entirely n the seasons, and that art had as yet done nothing to fence against the s of the heavens. During this reign, considerable improvements were e, as in most arts, so in this, the most beneficial of any. A numerous e might be formed of books and pamphlets treating of husbandry, h were written about this time. The nation, however, was still t on foreigners for daily bread; and though its exportation of n forms a considerable branch of its commerce, notwithstanding its e increase of people, there was, in that period, a regular n from the Baltic, as well as from France and if it ever d, the bad consequences were sensibly felt by the nation. Sir Walter Raleigh, in his Observations, computes that two millions went out at one e for corn. It was not till the fifth of Elizabeth, that the n of corn had been allowed in England; and Camden observes, that e from that moment received new life and vigor.



The endeavors of James, or, more properly speaking, those—of the n, for promoting trade, were attended with greater success than those r the encouragement of learning. Though the age was by no means e of eminent writers, a very bad taste in general prevailed during t period; and the monarch himself was not a little infected with it.



On the origin of letters among the Greeks, the genius of poets and s, as might naturally be expected, was distinguished by an amiable y, which, whatever rudeness may sometimes attend it, is so fitted o express the genuine movements of nature and passion, that the s possessed of it must ever appear valuable to the discerning t of mankind. The glaring figures of discourse, the pointed antithesis, e unnatural conceit, the jingle of words; such false ornaments were not d by early writers; not because they were rejected, but because y scarcely ever occurred to them. An easy, unforced strain of sentiment s through their compositions; though at the same time we may observe, t, amidst the most elegant simplicity of thought and expression, one is s surprised to meet with a poor conceit, which had presented f unsought for, and which the author had not acquired critical n enough to condemn.[*]



A bad taste seizes with avidity these frivolous beauties, and even perhaps a good taste, ere surfeited by them: they multiply every day more and more n the fashionable compositions: nature and good sense are neglected: d ornaments studied and admired: and a total degeneracy of style and e prepares the way for barbarism and ignorance. Hence the Asiatic r was found to depart so much from the simple purity of Athens: hence t tinsel eloquence which is observable in many of the Roman writers, m which Cicero himself is not wholly exempted, and which so much s in Ovid, Seneca, Lucan, Martial, and the Plinys.



On the revival of letters, when the judgment of the public is yet raw and d, this false glitter catches the eye, and leaves no room, either n eloquence or poetry, for the durable beauties of solid sense and lively n. The reigning genius is then diametrically opposite to that which s on the first origin of arts. The Italian writers, it is evident, n the most celebrated, have not reached the proper simplicity of t and composition; and in Petrarch, Tasso, Guarini, frivolous s and forced conceits are but too predominant. The period during h letters were cultivated in Italy was so short, as scarcely to allow e for correcting this adulterated relish.



The more early French writers are liable to the same reproach. Voiture, Balzac, even Coraeneille, have too much affected those ambitious s, of which the Italians in general, and the least pure of the s, supplied them with so many models. And it was not till late, t observation and reflection gave rise to a more natural turn of t and composition among that elegant people.



A like character may be extended to the first English writers; such as d during the reigns of Elizabeth and James, and even till long s. Learning, on its revival in this island, was attired in the e unnatural garb which it wore at the time of its decay among the Greeks and Romans. And, what may be regarded as a misfortune, the English s were possessed of great genius before they were endowed with any e of taste, and by that means gave a kind of sanction to those forced s and sentiments which they so much affected. Their distorted s and expressions are attended with such vigor of mind, that we e the imagination which produced them, as much as we blame the want f judgment which gave them admittance. To enter into an exact criticism f the writers of that age, would exceed our present purpose. A short r of the most eminent, delivered with the same freedom which y exercises over kings and ministers, may not be improper. The l prepossessions which prevail, will perhaps render the former y not the least perilous for an author.



If Shakspeare be considered as a man, born in a rude age, and educated in e lowest manner, without any instruction either from the world or from s, he may be regarded as a prodigy: if represented as a poet, capable f furnishing a proper entertainment to a refined or intelligent audience, e must abate much of this eulogy. In his compositions, we regret that y irregularities, and even absurdities, should so frequently disfigure e animated and passionate scenes intermixed with them; and at the same e, we perhaps admire the more those beauties, on account of their being d with such deformities. A striking peculiarity of sentiment d to a singular character, he frequently hits, as it were by n; but a reasonable propriety of thought he cannot for any time d. Nervous and picturesque expressions, as well as descriptions, d in him; but it is in vain we look either for purity or simplicity f diction. His total ignorance of all theatrical art and conduct, however l a defect, yet, as it affects the spectator rather than the r, we can more easily excuse, than that want of taste which often s in his productions, and which gives way only by intervals to the s of genius. A great and fertile genius he certainly possessed, d one enriched equally with a tragic and comic vein; but he ought to be d as a proof, how dangerous it is to rely on these advantages alone r attaining an excellence in the finer arts.[*] And there may even n a suspicion, that we overrate, if possible, the greatness of his s; in the same manner as bodies often appear more gigantic, on t of their being disproportioned and misshapen. He died in 1616, d fifty-three years.



Jonson possessed all the learning which was wanting to Shakspeare, and d all the genius of which the other was possessed. Both of them were y deficient in taste and elegance, in harmony and correctness. A e copyist of the ancients, Jonson translated into bad English the l passages of the Greek and Roman authors, without accommodating m to the manners of his age and country. His merit has been totally d by that of Shakspeare, whose rude genius prevailed over the rude t of his contemporary. The English theatre has ever since taken a strong e of Shakspeare’s spirit and character; and thence it has d, that the nation has undergone, from all its neighbors, the h of barbarism, from which its valuable productions in some other s of learning would otherwise have exempted it. Jonson had a pension f a hundred marks from the king, which Charles afterwards augmented to a d pounds He died in 1637, aged sixty-three.



Fairfax has translated Tasso with an elegance and ease, and at the same e with an exactness, which, for that age, are surprising. Each line in e original is faithfully rendered by a correspondent line in the n. Harrington’s translation of Ariosto is not likewise without s merit. It is to be regretted, that these poets should have imitated e Italians in their stanza, which has a prolixity and uniformity in it t displeases in long performances. They had, otherwise, as well as Spenser, who went before them, contributed much to the polishing and g of the English versification.



In Donne’s satires, when carefully inspected, there appear some flashes of t and ingenuity; but these totally suffocated and buried by the harshest d most uncouth expression that is any where to be met with.



If the poetry of the English was so rude and imperfect during that age, we y reasonably expect that their prose would be liable to still greater s. Though the latter appears the more easy, as it is the more l method of composition, it has ever in practice been found the more e and difficult; and there scarcely is an instance, in any language, t it has reached a degree of perfection, before the refinement of l numbers and expression. English prose, during the reign of James, s written with little regard to the rules of grammar, and with a total d to the elegance and harmony of the period. Stuffed with Latin s and quotations, it likewise imitated those inversions, which, r forcible and graceful in the ancient languages, are entirely y to the idiom of the English. I shall indeed venture to affirm, t, whatever uncouth phrases and expressions occur in old books, they e chiefly owing to the unformed taste of the author; and that the e spoken in the courts of Elizabeth and James, was very little t from that which we meet with at present in good company. Of this n, the little scraps of speeches which are found in the y journals, and which carry all air so opposite to the d: rations, seem to be a sufficient proof; and there want not s of that age, which, being written by men who were not authors y profession, retain a very natural manner, and may give us some idea of e language which prevailed among men of the world. I shall particularly n Sir John Davis’s Discovery. Throgmorton’s, Essex’s, and Nevil’s s. In a more early period, Cavendish’s life of Cardinal Wolsey, the s that remain of Bishop Gardiner, and Anne Boleyn’s letter to the g, differ little or nothing from the language of our time.



The great glory of literature in this island during the reign of James, s Lord Bacon. Most of his performances were composed in Latin; though he d neither the elegance of that, nor of his native tongue. If we r the variety of talents displayed by this man, as a public r, a man of business, a wit, a courtier, a companion, an author, a r, he is justly the object of great admiration. If we consider m merely as an author and philosopher, the light in which we view him at t, though very estimable, he was yet inferior to his contemporary Galilaeo, perhaps even to Kepler. Bacon pointed out at a distance the road o true philosophy: Galilaeo both pointed it out to others, and made f considerable advances in it. The Englishman was ignorant of y: the Florentine revived that science, excelled in it, and was the t that applied it, together with experiment, to natural philosophy.

The former rejected, with the most positive disdain, the system of Copernicus: the latter fortified it with new proofs, derived both from n and the senses. Bacon’s style is stiff and rigid: his wit, though n brilliant, is also often unnatural and far-fetched; and he seems to e the original of those pointed similes and long-spun allegories which so h distinguish the English authors: Galilaeo is a lively and agreeable, h somewhat a prolix writer. But Italy not united in any single t, and perhaps satiated with that literary glory which it has d both in ancient and modern times, has too much neglected the n which it has acquired by giving birth to so great a man. That l spirit which prevails among the English, and which forms their t happiness, is the cause why they bestow on all their eminent s, and on Bacon among the rest, such praises and acclamations as may n appear partial and excessive. He died in 1626, in the sixty-sixth r of his life.



If the reader of Raleigh’s history can have the patience to wade through e Jewish and rabbinical learning which compose the half of the volume, e will find, when he comes to the Greek and Roman story, that his pains e not unrewarded. Raleigh is the best model of that ancient style which e writers would affect to revive at present. He was beheaded in 1618, d sixty-six years.



Camden’s history of Queen Elizabeth may be esteemed good composition, both r style and matter. It is written with simplicity of expression, very e in that age, and with a regard to truth. It would not perhaps be too h to affirm, that it is among the best historical productions which e yet been composed by any Englishman. It is well known that the English have not much excelled in that kind of literature. He died in

1623, aged seventy-three years.



We shall mention the king himself at the end of these English writers; e that is his place, when considered as an author. It may safely be d, that the mediocrity of James’s talents in literature, joined to e great change in national taste, is one cause of that contempt under h his memory labors, and which is often carried by party writers to a t extreme. It is remarkable, how different from ours were the s of the ancients with regard to learning. Of the first twenty Roman emperors, counting from Caesar to Severus, above the half were s; and though few of them seem to have been eminent in that n, it is always remarked to their praise, that by their example y encouraged literature. Not to mention Germanicus, and his daughter Agrippina, persons so nearly allied to the throne, the greater part of the c writers whose works remain, were men of the highest quality. As y human advantage is attended with inconveniencies, the change of n’s ideas in this particular may probably be ascribed to the invention f printing; which has rendered books so common, that even men of slender s can have access to them.



That James was but a middling writer, may be allowed: that he was a e one, can by no means be admitted. Whoever will read his Basilicon Doron, particularly the two last books, the true law of free s, his answer to Cardinal Perron, and almost all his speeches and s to parliament, will confess him to have possessed no mean genius.

If he wrote concerning witches and apparitions; who, in that age did not t the reality of these fictitious beings? If he has composed a y on the Revelations, and proved the pope to be Antichrist; may t a similar reproach be extended to the famous Napier; and even to Newton, at a time when learning was much more advanced than during the n of James? From the grossness of its superstitions we may infer the e of an age; but never should pronounce concerning the folly of an l, from his admitting popular errors, consecrated by the e of religion.



Such a superiority do the pursuits of literature possess above every other n, that even he who attains but a mediocrity in them, merits the eÃ«minence above those that excel the most in the common and vulgar s. The speaker of the house of commons is usually an eminent r; yet the harangue of his majesty will always be found much superior o that of the speaker, in every parliament during this reign.



Every science, as well as polite literature, must be considered as being t in its infancy. Scholastic learning and polemical divinity retarded e growth of all true knowledge. Sir Henry Saville, in the preamble of t deed by which he annexed a salary to the mathematical and l professors in Oxford, says, that geometry was almost totally d and unknown in England.[*] The best learning of that age was the y of the ancients. Casaubon, eminent for this species of knowledge, s invited over from France by James, and encouraged by a pension of e hundred pounds a year, as well as by church preferments.[**] The s Antonio di Dominis, archbishop of Spalatro, no despicable r, came likewise into England, and afforded great triumph to the n, by their gaining so considerable a proselyte from the Papists. But e mortification followed soon after: the archbishop, though advanced to e ecclesiastical preferments.[***] received not encouragement t to satisfy his ambition; he made his escape into Italy, where e died in confinement.

The mistake y be accounted for; the letters were only written by her; the second t with Bothwell was only subscribed. A proper accurate distinction s not made; and they are all said to be written and subscribed. A late r, Mr. Goodall, has endeavored to prove that these letters clash with y, and that the queen was not in the places mentioned in the s on the days there assigned. To confirm this, he produces charters d other deeds signed by the queen, where the date and place do not agree h the letters. But it is well known, that the date of charters, and h like grants, is no proof of the real day on which they were signed by e sovereign. Papers of that kind commonly pass through different s. The date is affixed by the first office, and may precede very g the day of the signature.  The account given by Morton of e manner in which the papers came into his hands, is very natural. When e gave it to the English commissioners, he had reason to think it would e canvassed with all the severity of able adversaries, interested in the t degree to refute it. The sonnets are inelegant; insomuch that both Brantome and Bonsard, who knew Queen Mary’s style, were assured, when they saw them, t they could not be of her composition. Jebb, voL ii p. 478. But no n is equal in his productions, especially one whose style is so e formed as Mary’s must be supposed to be. Not to mention, that such s and criminal enterprises leave little tranquillity of mind for t poetical compositions.  In a word, Queen Mary might y have conducted the whole conspiracy against her husband, without g her mind to any one person except Bothwell, and without writing a p of paper about it; but it was very difficult to have conducted it so t her conduct should not betray her to men of discernment. In the t case, her conduct was so gross as to betray her to every body; and e threw into her enemies’ hands papers by which they could convict r. The same infatuation and imprudence, which happily is the usual t of great crimes, will account for both. It is proper to observe, t there is not one circumstance of the foregoing narrative, contained n the history, that is taken from Knox, Buchanan, or even Thuanus, or d from any suspected authority.]

61 (return) [ NOTE III, p. 499.

“Monarchies,” according to Sir Walter Raleigh, “are of two sorts touching r power or authority, viz. 1. Entire, where the whole power of g all state matters, both in peace and war, doth by law and custom n to the prince, as in the English kingdom; where the prince hath e power to make laws, league, and war, to create magistrates, to pardon e, of appeal, etc. Though to give a contentment to the other degrees, y have a suffrage in making laws, yet ever subject to the prince’s e and negative will. 2. Limited or restrained, that hath no full r in all the points and matters of state, as the military king that h not the sovereignty in time of peace, as the making of laws, etc., t in war only, as the Polonian king.” Maxims of State.  And a e after: “In every just state, some part of the government is, or t to be, imparted to the people, as in a kingdom, a voice and suffrage n making laws; and sometimes also of levying of arms, (if the charge be t, and the prince forced to borrow help of his subjects,) the matter y may be propounded to a parliament, that the tax may seem to have d from themselves. So consultations and some proceedings in l matters may in part be referred to them. The reason, lest, seeing s to be in no number nor of reckoning, they mislike the state or t.” This way of reasoning differs little from that of King James, o considered the privileges of the parliament as matters of grace and e, more than of inheritance. It is remarkable that Raleigh was t to lean towards the Puritanical party, notwithstanding these s. But ideas of government change much in different times.

Raleigh’s sentiments on this head are still more openly expressed in his Prerogatives of Parliaments, a work not published till after his death. It s a dialogue between a courtier, or counsellor, and a country justice of e, who represents the patriot party, and defends the highest notion of y which the principles of that age would bear. Here is a passage of t: “Counsellor. That which is done by the king, with the advice of his e or privy council, is done by the king’s absolute power. Justice.

And by whose power is it done in parliament but by the king’s absolute r? Mistake it not, my lord: the three estates do but advise as the y council doth; which advice if the king embrace, it becomes the g’s own act in the one, and the king’s law in the other,” etc.

The genius f the ancient government reposed more trust in the king, than to n any such suspicion; and it allowed scattered instances of such a d, as would have been totally destructive of the constitution, had they n continued without interruption.  I have not met with any English writer in that age who speaks of England as a limited monarchy, t as an absolute one, where the people have many privileges. That is no n. In all European monarchies the people have privileges; but r dependent or independent on the will of the monarch, is a question t in most governments it is better to forbear. Surely that question was t determined before the age of James. The rising spirit of the t, together with that king’s love of general, speculative s, brought it from its obscurity, and made it be commonly d. The strongest testimony that I remember from a writer of James’s age in favor of English liberty, is in Cardinal Bentivoglio, a r, who mentions the English government as similar to that of the Low Country provinces under their princes, rather than to that of France r Spain. Englishmen were not so sensible that their prince was limited, e they were sensible that no individual had any security against a h of prerogative: but foreigners, by comparison, could perceive that e stretches were at that time, from custom or other causes, less t in England than in other monarchies.
